description:
I hear people talking about the long lines at this place, yet I haven't experienced those yet. Maybe because I come really early in the morning or just before they're closing? (Must be all the techies living in this Area who don't roll out of bed until 9am!)

Anyways, I really like this place. Their baked goods, of course, are a delight and I've yet have to have an item that I didn't like. My go-to is the sourdough bread - the one in square format. Ideally they will slice it for me so that i can just put it in a plastic bag and pop it into the freezer: it's delicious for breakfast on the weekends as it pairs so well with my homemade blackberry jam. 

Aside from their baked goods though, I love the workers' attitude here: I frequent a lot of bakeries all throughout San Francisco and one thing I always note is that the people working their are not very friendly. To the point of being snotty. Here at Neighbor Bakehouse I have only experienced friendly smiles and a welcoming attitude.
author: Uli B.

description:
Dish: Ginger Pull-Apart
Cost: $4.25
Rating: 4.25/5
Review: Came here on a recommendation from a friend since I was in the area and I was pleasantly surprised! I'm still in the process of getting used to eating ginger and ginger flavored things. I used to hate ginger and the flavor but I'm trying to be more open to it since it's good for you. This has a strong ginger taste but not all over - mainly on the bottom, so I did really enjoy this pastry! I'm still not super accustomed to the taste so if you like ginger and love the ginger taste, you'll probably rate this a 5/5. For me, I'm not quite there yet but I did enjoy the parts that weren't so gingery. The pastry is delicious but I wish they kept them warm to eat fresh but I'm sure there's a reason why they don't. I was nervous there would be a long line or they would be sold out since this is what they're known for but there was no line and plenty to get! They have all their pastry items on a cart and on trays side by side for the worker to put into bags for you. Next time I'll definitely try other items! So happy to find a spot where there's no ridiculous line and quality sweet and savory items!  There's literally one space designated for this spot on the sidewalk next to their entrance. The surrounding area is kinda hard to find parking. I'll def be back!
author: Valerie T.

description:
The complexity of this croissant makes up for the 15 minute line out the door and the price. Never have I heard of a twice-baked croissant! What is this sorcery? Pure magic! You'd think it'd be burnt or something, but it had that perfect crunch, was light, moist, and had the perfect density. Like I could actually eat this all at once, but I didn't because...calories. Pistachio and blackberry went together well, surprisingly. The cookie-like crust on top was delicious and added a nice contrast in texture to the croissant. The filling wasn't overly sweet, and I seriously could not stop eating this. I had to force myself to put it away and save the rest for the following day. 

Also the smells wafting out of the bakery. Ahhh. I could smell it all the way at the end of the line.

The cashier was super friendly and there are so many options to choose from. He helped me choose this croissant and I did not regret my choice. Although you can't regret or be disappointed with anything here, really.
author: Megan H.

description:
Neighbor Bakehouse, you never bor me away. 

This is my all time favorite bakery in San Francisco. 
Situated right off 3rd street with an expansive outdoor seating area by San Francisco standards, this bakery is hard to miss on weekends as the wait is usually in the range of 20-45 minutes, depending on the time of day. 

With fresh baked batches of assorted pastries made on site every hour or so, the aromas of the varying depths of flavors - berries; chocolate; pear; ginger; roasted nuts - burst through the air and grab your soul. 

My favorite picks are:

(1) The Cinnamon Almond Bostock - I love this pastry because it is a cross between a French toast and a croissant - the child that got the best genes from both parents. Crisp and buttery on the outside, soft layered and airy on the inside, with the flavor of the roasted almonds and cinnamon throughout.  The perfect start to any day. 

(2) The ginger pull apart - The way this bread is twisted not only makes this bread a fun pull apart to share with friends, but it is also positioned as to maximize the surface area and optimize the crunch effect - and add to that the flavor of the fiery ginger. This is another classic. 

(3) The Twice Baked Croissants - I really enjoy the various flavors of the twice makes. The way that the berries complement the herbs, all baked inside a twice baked croissant for that added crunchy texture makes for a complex flavor combination with varying debts of texture. 

(4) The Kimchee Toast - On top the buttery, fresh thick milk toast are the tart kimchee, scallions, and cheese.  Though I have a sweet tooth, I quite enjoy the savory bread on occasion.  The one thing that makes this one more enjoyable is reheating it - else the kimchee-cheese-scallion is easy to separate from the toast and the situation gets messy. 

The tea and coffee are also carefully made cup by cup - a good wake up call. 

Neighbor Bakehouse, I'm so happy we are neighbors.
author: Vivienne K.

description:
I've been to Neighbor Bakehouse multiple times and they have yet to disappoint!

I usually go early in the morning and see what they have available. Everything I've had has been great but my favorites as of right now are the Everything Croissant and the Guava and Cheese Pastelito! If you are a fan of bagels and cream cheese in the morning, the Everything Croissant has cream cheese on the inside. Yum! The Guava and Cheese Pastelito also remind me of Porto's. 

I like to come here when I get the chance. Definitely one of the best bakeries in SF!
author: Michael L.

description:
Went here on a Sunday a little after 9 and only 10 people in front and behind us. We were also lucky to get a parking spot in a space in the parking lot area.

The inside is small and only 6-8 people can fit in there but with 2 people helping you pick out items the line moves fairly quickly. The bottleneck is the 1 cashier and then having to wait for your drink.

No seating inside but definitely a little bit outside, and it was dog friendly too.

It is kind of neat to see the bakers baking everything there in front of you as you are picking out items and placing your order.

There are plenty of treats to choose from including pie, cookies, croissants, tarts, bread, croque madadme, etc. The prices range from $3 to $9.

We ordered several things including a loaf of sourdough bread, gingerbread cookie, butter croissant, chocolate croissant, croque madame, and a raspberry violet twice-baked. 

I got to try the raspberry violet twice-baked, and it was delicious. It is covered in powdered sugar so be prepared to get that all over you but it was flavorful from beginning to end. Each bite better than before especially when you get to the fruit packed middle. It hit the spot and prepared me for a long hike.

Everyone else liked their items as well.
author: Keith A.

description:
The BEST bakery in the area. This is the kind of place where you go to buy some pastries during your lunch break with the intention of taking them home to eat later, except you end up eating it all before you leave work...

It's a super lowkey spot and it's only open Wednesday - Sunday until early afternoon so make sure you check their hours! 
If you're here during lunch hours make sure to try their sandwiches too! Their turkey is my personal favorite but, honestly, everything is delicious.
author: Jenny L.

description:
Street parking was easy for 9:30 on Sun morning.
Lined up outside and ate outside at communal picnic tables.  The vibe is relaxed and laid back. 
The weather in Jun was typical morning overcast, not too cold, not too hot.  It was perfect weather to eat outside.  But I can imagine the short raining season when it might not work for alfresco dining.
Seems like all the pastries  we ate was a croissant derivative, real buttery and flaky, 5 starts for each item.

Everything Croissant - seeds and nuts on the outside, soft cream cheese on the inside, I can imagine being in France.

Ham and Cheese morning bun - savory with sweet 

Raspberry hazelnut twice-bake -  smallest and sweetest of the bunch, very moist with the fresh fruit

Ginger pullapart - my son's favorite, largest pastry we got, very little hint of ginger taste, reminds me of monkey bread but better

Cinnamon Almond Bostock - This is almond fantasy, cake like toast with almond taste, my personal favorite
author: Connie W.

description:
The pastries here are actually pretty good! I was impressed by the quality and the fact that they had a pretty fresh taste to them.

I had the German something and it had this beautiful crumble on top of a croissant like texture with a lovely berry jam on the inside. The thing whole pasty was delightful.

It is a little pricy, around $4 for my item but still pretty enjoyable regardless.
author: Tyler T.

description:
This bakery is heaven-sent. I am usually never in this neighborhood, but I was craving something sweet and I did a quick search on Yelp for bakeries...

One thing lead to another and I was eating their delicious pastries. I got a raspberry twice baked one that was an epic flurry of magical flavours in my mouth. I left half of it in the fridge and forgot about it only to come across it again two days later and it still tasted AMAZING. 

They have outdoor seating in the form of long picnic benches in the sun. 

Definitely coming back to this gem.
author: Cynthia G.

description:
Neighbor Bakehouse really is a neighborhood gem! Plenty of high-quality pastries (my Everything Croissant has really raised the bar for Everything Bagels), and it just seems that there's no going wrong with any of their choices.

My friend went with the Kim-Chi Bake. We were both a little surprised that there's cheese on it, but I enjoyed it anyhow haha. And returning to my Everything Croissant - it was just so flaky and delicious. I know some people really enjoy their Costco croissants, and I do heart Costco too - but these croissants just taste much more fresh and don't have that "weird butter aftertaste". Gosh, I really should have gotten 2...

As for the venue itself, Neighbor Bakehouse is situated in a small shop on a busy street (with a climbing gym nearby). Parking isn't that easy, but if you drive to the back of the complex, there should be better luck there. The shop itself has outdoor seating only, so be prepared to eat on the go or to dress for the weather. Lines seemed to average between 5-15min, depending if you catch a lucky break.

Overall, I'll definitely be bringing more friends here, especially post-climbs :) Really solid bakery!
author: Greg G.

description:
Everything about this place is amazing besides the location. The Dogpatch is a pain to get to/around if you bike or take public transit. My longish bike ride involved cracked roads, train tracks, and lotsa air pollution.

Maybe it's for the best this place is off the beaten path though. The line moved quick but was out the door the whole time I was here, and the outdoor benches were full the whole time. Would probably be a bit too packed in a more central part of town. Here though, it was just packed enough for a fun and busy vibe without being overly crowded.

Everyone's willing to make the trek because these are some goood pastries. The blackberry pistachio twice baked (~$5) was deliciously sweet and flaky. There could have been more pistachio but every time I got a bite of some it was perfect. The lemon olive sourdough was also delicious--not too sour with a perfect texture.

On a sunny weekend morning, I highly recommend this place. Even if you don't live in the neighborhood it's worth trying at least once! If the trek doesn't sound worth it to you, I believe they also sell some of their delicious baked goods at coffee shops throughout the city, which you can locate on their website.
author: Audrey S.

description: Amazing pistachio double bake. You can never go wrong  with the cappuccino either. Our only mistake was not getting two of each :)
author: Hari N.

description:
Got here around noon on a Saturday with about 10 people in line and a 15 minute or so wait.

Ginger pull apart bun-- I was hoping for a heavier ginger flavor, but this had a light ginger flavor. It was easy to pull apart, with a good mix of flaky and bready, but the butteriness and crunchiness is still better at Arsicault. 3.5/5

The fruit tart was like a Danish, decently moist but could have been a bit more moist in my opinion. The berries weren't too sweet and the custard didn't stand out too much to me. I felt that this was more of a 3.25/5.

Clearly I'm missing the hype on this place though since there's a 5/5 on this spot!
author: Nicole H.

description:
OMG!!!!!!! THIS PLACE IS THE BOMB!!!!

I don't even like pastries, but my sister kept raving about how life changing the Pistachio Croissant was, so of course even though I resisted a bit, I was dragged.
Being up at the crack of dawn to catch a flight and then having to look for parking for 30 minutes, I was sooooo over it!  BUT, my sister was right, the pastries were life changing.  
Everything we got, ALL 5 things are perfectly done.  Enough crisp and crunch on the outside, but inside was nice and moist.  Most of all, it was perfectly sweetened, so much so that we killed all 5 things within 30 minutes. 

The place is small inside, but you grab your items to go or if the weather is nice, there are a few tables outside.  
OH!  Don't let me forget, they had NITRO cold brew that was super yumms!  

I will definitely be coming back here, maybe via uber next time! haahah
author: Panuly F.

description:
These croissants...more like crackssants. 

I really like a good cookie -- especially chocolate chip. This was a good cookie. This croissant, was better. YES I said it. Me, cookie lover and disliker of flaky desserts enjoyed the croissant more than the cookie.

It was already a damn good cookie, which shows you how amazing the croissant is. That everything topping. That filling (cream cheese-esqu which I usually hate). Buttery, flaky, yum!

The cookie. Chewy, dense, chocolatey. Great baking job, great bakery.

I wish this was my Neighbor Bakehouse! Actually, it's probably better that it isn't.
author: Libby J.

description:
Yummmmmm!!! Basically, if you're a bakery - I already love you! You keep me and my carb-intensive diet running...whether good or bad - i dunno! But at least it's happy!

Came here on a friend's recommendation...where they didnt really manage my expectations well because they kept saying it was the best bakery in SF. Wow. lol...bar was set.

I ordered:

Butter Croissant - Ultra crispy and flakey! It basically crumbled EVERYWHERE when I bit into it! Whoops. good thing no more in-person meetings today!

Pistachio BlackBerry Danish - Perfect if you want something sweet and nutty...was perfect with their PERFECTLY made latte! So good!

Kimchi Toast - Good, but not great! Probably should've toasted it or warmed it up a little..

Ham and Gruyere croissant - shaped like a muffin, except it was crispy and awesome like the tops of croissants!

This skyrocketed this bakery to one of the top bakeries on my list ...esp since its so close to the Muni stop too! A+ for being more accessible to me even though it is in the Dogpatch area! yayyeeee!
author: Jennifer S.

description:
We were here on a Sunday at around 10:45am and the line was already out the door. It only got longer as time went by!

We ordered a Mushroom Tart ($4.50), a Sauerkraut Smoked Cheddar Peppadew Tart ($4.50), a slice of Chocolate Pudding Pie ($7.00), a small baguette, and 2 Drip Coffees. 

Mushroom Tart had a nice layers of pastry crust. The Sauerkraut Tart was a tad spicy and had a nice smoky flavor. I loved he Chocolate Pudding Pie! It was decadent and creamy. I was not a fan of the crust as it was a bit hard and I couldn't cut it with a fork. I also wish it was served colder. The baguette was pretty good with a nice shell and chewy inside. 

Outside seating was nice and my dog also enjoyed this place! I'm looking forward to coming back here to try their Fruit Tart! We were not early enough this time!
author: Alice L.

description:
I came early in the morning on a Sunday, and I really loved the quaint neighborhood where the bakery is located. Parking was very easy, and free on Sundays, which was a plus. The store is very small, but there's a line that's not too long for their pastries. 

At around 9am, the line wasn't too bad, and I was able to get in and out in about 10 minutes. I ordered an assortment of pastries, including croissants, ginger pull-parts, and the everything croissant, and the size of the pastries was definitely worth the price. 

My favorite of the pastries was definitely the ginger-pull apart! It reminded me of a kougin Aman, but it was a lot bigger (which is never a complaint). The ginger flavor didn't shine through too much, but I loved the caramel texture and crispy parts of the pastry. Also, it's a fun pastry to eat, since it somewhat resembles baked monkey bread with croissant dough. 

These pastries also last a few days without getting soggy! I had them for about three days, and a few minutes in the oven brought them back to life. 

I would highly recommend this bakery if you're in the area. It is more of a small, quaint bakery, but their pastries and flavor combinations are worth the try.
author: Sandra S.

description: Overall the setting was really nice. The cappuccino was priced cheap but tasted really well. Also the guava and cheese pastry was really great. Not as good as the ones from Miami but really well done. Really great people who work there and the food was perfect for what they served. They seem to have a lot of regulars. Really means a lot from a restaurant standpoint. Highly recommend to anyone coming to San Fran
author: Adrian M.

description:
Finally got to go here! At 1pm on a Saturday, there was a short line and seats available outside, but they were out of a few baked goods. 

* Cinnamon Almond Bostock ($4.50) - 4 stars
This was soft & delicious! Especially for a french toast lover like me.

After they closed at 2pm, they left a tray of free goodies and bags outside! I got some ciabatta bread, a croissant, and a muffin.
author: Ziyan C.

description:
Wow this place is good. 

Can we talk baked goods folks? Cuz this place knows their stuff. 

The guava twice baked thing and the pistachio twice baked thing and the passion fruit filled pastry and the almond bostock and chocolate filled pastry thing and so on and so forth....

All the food is amazing. I wish they were closer to me so it wouldn't be such a hike for me.

How does it stack up compared to the other great bakeries in the city? I think they're better than Mr Holmes, Tartine, ... but not B Patisserie- while the goodies are similar in awesomeness, B has better service, slightly better prices, and friendlier staff. Only difference imo.
author: Mandi W.

description: This is a nice little spot, but at the end of day, you're waiting in line for bread/croissants. Its good, but its hard for me to give anything higher than 3 stars.
author: Jorge P.

description:
If there's a line out the door, don't be alarmed! This place doesn't have much space inside for people to wait and the line moves pretty quickly. Came here on a Saturday morning and had about a 10 minute wait to get in to order. My party of four ordered the Kimchi toast, Croque Madame, Almond Bostock, Pistachio Croissant, Guava/cream cheese Pastelito and a passion fruit cream pastry. We sat out on a picnic table and cut each in quarters so we could try a bit of each. They were all fabulous! The Bostock was my favorite. It was a piece of brioche with almonds and frangipane, lightly sweet and very delicious.

Bottom Line: If you're in the area, definitely stop by for a pastry! They also had lots of delicious looking breads for sale.
author: Kim P.

description:
So at this point I've tried every regular item on their menu. I find there is a common taste thread that goes through all of their pastries: Rich, buttery, and delectable. 

Wow bonus points because the coffee is to die for. This place and Tartine serve the best coffee I've had in the city. In full disclosure, I don't like blue bottle and other artisan (bitter!) coffees, which I gather that everyone else in SF likes, judging by the lines at Blue bottle. 

Why not 5 stars? Because if you get more than 2 or 3 pastries, they all start tasting the same, and a big pastry pit starts forming in the bottom of your stomach. Heaviness you carry around all day.  But I guess your asking for it if you eat 3 pastries.
author: Sheewon B.

description:
Holy moly, this has got to be one of the best bakeries I've been to in a while. Their croissants (tried both the regular and pistachio twice-baked) are excellent - buttery, fluffy, and fresh. My friend also got a cookie and it was so chewy and delicious! On the pricer side, but so worth. 

Side note: they close early and tend to sell out early, just a heads up! Their stuff is good, so make sure you can grab what you can get.
author: Ashley C.

description: Love this spot! Great drinks, amazing pastries, and wonderful people. On a mission to try all of the pastries, so far I have had the ginger pull apart and it was heavenly. They also have oat milk!
author: Shabnam E.

description:
hypehypehype this is a bakery totally worth visiting in SF in addition to the typical tartine/mr holmes/etc

I got the twice baked pistachio blackberry croissant, and it was absolutely delicious. The crunchy addition of the pistachio adds another layer of texture in addition to the flaky croissant. The croissant was a bit too sweet for me, but the blackberry filling was indeed fruity and on point. 

The outdoor seating is nice because we should all enjoy the outdoors more, but it can suck when the sun is in your face. 

The workers are super chill and amazing. This really cute little kid was grabbing a glass cup of water, but his smol hands had trouble gripping the rim, so the cup slipped from his grasp and shattered into many sharp pieces. The worker was super nice and told the little boy and his dad not to worry, and that his dishwasher will be super happy. LOL what a great sense of humor.
author: Tiffany H.

description:
My friend took me here this morning. Carbs? Hell yeah, I'm in! There was a bit of a line out the door, but it was moving quick. The storefront was tiny - what do you expect out of San Francisco. 

Most of the pastries were on a rack. An employee grabs your pastries and bags 'em for you as well. They have a mixture of savory and sweet pastries. I got one of each - the everything croissant and the pistachio raspberry croissant twice baked. 

As a person that prefers savory foods, I LOVED the everything croissant. Before I tried it, I was quite confused as to what an everything croissant entailed; I mean, I knew what an everything bagel was, but still very confused. And yes, it had everything (duh), including the cream cheese inside. I was in love with this one. 

I didn't finish the pistachio raspberry croissant only because I just had a whole everything croissant and I'm lowkey watching my weight, ha!

I came back at 12 noon and bought two more to bring home for the fam (I would have bought more, but San Francisco inflated prices do apply here, lol). I brought home another sweet twice-baked croissant and a dessert bar. As much as I forgot the names, I'm sure the taste will not be forgetful!

My friend got two as well - sauerkraut + cheddar croissant and the other sweet, twice-baked croissant. She didn't care much for the sauerkraut one - so, not recommended if you don't like sauerkraut.

Quick Notes:
- Everything ranges from $3-$8
- Street only parking, but it shouldn't be too hard to find parking
- Cash and credit card taken
- Seating is limited
author: Nicole D.

description:
Was in the city for a birthday party and lucked into finding this trendy, quintessentially sf bakery.

A fair amount of twice baked stuff like the hazelnut raspberry croissant. Kids loved the passion fruit cream filled pastry, bright flavors. Almond french toast thing wasnt bad.
author: Philip L.

description:
I first got to know about this place because a friend of a friend worked here . Checked it out once and it wasn't long before it became a Saturday morning tradition. I think I have tried almost all the items on the menu but I now stick to the double baked croissant and the curry puff for the perfect sweet and savory combination. Their coffee is spectacularly good !!! I have now moved farther away and miss this place dearly!

There is no parking right there, but u can find lots of spots a block away ..If you are a party of 1+ recommend to drop 1 person to stand in line, while you park :)
author: Anju J.

description:
Can't believe I didn't hear about this place earlier!!! We actually stumbled upon this bakery while we were waiting for a spot at aina.

The croissant alone earns this place its 5 stars - buttery, flakey, perfectly laminated, chewy inside...as good as it gets outside of France. Love the first bite, which is slightly crunchy. Get a napkin and eat carefully, as the flakes are sure to get all over your shirt!  

Other yummy things we got: the twice baked croissants (raspberry version and pistachio version) - both lovely, but definitely on the sweeter side, approaching cloying for this future diabetic. Ginger pullapart was light on the ginger, in that there was more of a subtle spiciness as opposed to a full blown ginger flavor (which I enjoyed, but also disappointed someone else in my party who wanted more ginger).

I'm definitely coming back for more...*loosens belt*

Tip: Don't be frightened away by the line, it moves pretty fast!
author: Anna C.

description:
Great pastries, the usual (high) San Francisco prices, and good coffee.
What I really loved about their pastries is their originality - you can't find some of these anywhere else. Their execution is top notch: everything is fresh and delicious.

Drawbacks: parking is a pain and opening hours are so limited.
author: Hagit K.

description:
This place was busy on a Saturday around noon!

First time coming to this place and it had a small line that moved fairly quickly as they're very efficient at placing your orders.

Got the croque monsieur which was slightly disappointing since it didn't really taste like a pastry and felt more like an open faced sandwich. We also got the bread pudding which was DELICIOUS - carmelized and sweet - I would highly recommend it! My fiance got the ham and cheese and she loved it. Overall, quick and efficient service with great pastry items and a wide selection.
author: Alan C.

description: Delicious pastries and well worth the wait.
author: Kathy O.

description: Try the twice baked pistachio and blackberry pastry!! So good! And the mushroom tart! Really cute and quaint. The people are also sweet and helpful and it got quite busy quickly!
author: Archana W.

description: GINGER PULL APART! You should visit this place just base on that name. Seriously, I do not normally eat pastries, but this place got me shamelessly eating multiple of those ginger pull apart, MULTIPLES. It might sound weird, but it was the perfect combination that you normally wouldn't try. We got a box for the team and I kept visiting that box throughout the day.
author: Jie L.

description:
This just might be my new favorite bakery in SF!  

I came here on a Saturday morning and easily spotted the bakery based on the line snaking down the block. The cashiers here work efficiently, so it felt like no time before I made it to the beginning of the line. Once I was inside the bakery, I was confronted with an onslaught of delicious-looking pastries. I wanted to order EVERYTHING. After hearing rave reviews about the cinnamon almond bostock, I ordered one and I am so glad I did. What a decadent pastry bursting with almond flavor! My friend ordered the ham and cheese morning bun which was also heavenly -- the croissant dough is light, buttery perfection. 

Despite being crowded on a Saturday morning, my friends and I were able to snag a spot at the outdoor tables. There's nothing better than enjoying a beautiful San Francisco day with a delicious pastry and coffee in hand. My only complaint is that I have to travel all the way to the Dogpatch to get my pastry fix. 

Pistachio blackberry twice-baked croissant, I'm coming back for you!
author: Elyse W.

description:
The raspberry twice baked is hands down one of the best things I have ever stuffed my face with. Being anywhere in close proximity of this little bakery is a dangerous thing for my wallet and waistline.

Yes, it's pricy! But I've never had anything I regretted buying from here. The coconut pecan chocolate cookie is a buttery delight that is the size of my face. You can taste the fresh berries in the oat bars. I had the cinnamon bostock and the german coffee cake too, and they were both pretty good. I think I greatly prefer the croissants and flaky pastries from here even though cakes and breads are usually my go-to's. Come here before noon if you want the greatest selection, and don't be afraid of the line!
author: Sumaiya M.

description:
SF bakeries have my heart. And clearly everyone else's too. Even though bakery service is much faster than table service, there's still such a long line at all times in the day. 

The drive to Dogpatch was also beautiful, you get some scenic views of The City! It's a bit windy, so guard your stuff as you eat your food outside.

The almond Bostock $4.75 costs a lot, but there's absolutely nothing wrong with it. It's a French Toast, but better. It's got a crunchy outside crust with a moist, sweet, fluffy center. I loved the almond on this. I was so tempted to finish the whole thing.

The ginger pull apart $4.25 (?) was a lot bigger than I thought! Compared to pictures on Yelp at least. It's very comparable to a kouign amann. If you like crossiants, you'll love this guy. Don't worry if you don't like ginger, I didn't taste much of it. 

I'm not in this area much, but if I was, I'd definitely pick up their Everything crossiant or one of their sandwiches next time!
author: Lilian K.

description:
I'm so obsessed with the passion fruit doughp bun from here!! It's passion fruit cream in it is perfectly tart and sweet, and I love all things pastries.... Aside from the doughp bun though, everything sweet I've has here been delicious! They do a good job of making fresh flaky pastries (like the guava and cheese pastelito) as well as delicious breads.

The only downside is that there is usually a long line out the door, that can definitely be intimidating but it usually goes by pretty quick. Also, I have yet to try more savory items here but I tried the smoked salmon and cream cheese croissant and it wasn't very good. There was an aggressive amount of sesames on top and there was barely any filling inside the croissant. I'm not sure if this was just a one off situation, but I would definitely just recommend sticking to the sweet items!
author: Jacqueline T.

description:
One of my favorite bakeries in SF and it is my BF's very favorite bakery in SF.  Super cute bakery in dogpatch with outdoor seating.  You honestly cannot go wrong with anything here, both savory and sweet.  

First off, you must get one of their twice baked croissants.  We have tried the blackberry pistachio and raspberry hazelnut, we prefer the raspberry one but both our good.

You have to try a "doughpbun", they are custard filled buns.  It is generously filled and they make good custard.  Our favorite is the passionfruit but they have chocolate and guava too.  

Ginger pull apart, like a large kougin amman; it is caramelized monkey bread almost.  The ginger is just enough.  

For savory, the curry potato, sauerkraut cheddar tart, kimchee toast, and croque madame.  All excellent but if I had to pick a favorite probably the sauerkraut cheddar.  What's nice about the kimchee and croque, they have an egg on top of it and they will warm it up for you too. 

They have great bread too, we love buying a loaf there (only $6) and making good toasts at home.  This is the bread that is used at the Mill (where it is $5 a toast, so buy a loaf here and make it at home!).

This place is a little out of the way but worth the trek.  There is always a line on the weekends but a great place to check out!
author: Lauren S.

description:
This place needs to stop. Just stop; at the rate I'm going to be broke by the end of the month. I just moved to the dog patch ~2 months ago and we were fortunate enough to discover this place early on. What an absolute treat. Their baked goods are incredible; that includes the the sweet, savory and take home size loads. 

Sweet - The Ginger Pull Apart is my hands down favorite. Sweet, slightly crunchy on the outside, incredibly moist on the inside. Can't go wrong.

Savory - I've had a lot of their savory recipes, all good. Ham and cheese morning bun is great, the curried potato is great, even the sauerkraut tart was an absolute delight. 

Loafs- we get a loaf of ciabatta a week. It usually doesn't last more than 2 days. It's that good. 

They sell out daily by early afternoon. Also - though they open at at 6:30, they don't always have everything baked and ready for purchase right when they open - something to keep in mind (small space not a lot of ovens etc).

Enjoy!
author: Valentin G.

description:
TL;DR .. pricey and not very nicey.

Two stars because there are usually dogs, and it's less than a block away from amazing pizza, ice cream and other places with employees who aren't rude.

The barrista from Sunday morning (7/8) can polish up their people skills...
author: Jona N.

description:
Damn, I'm writing this review against my own best interests. 

I should be hiding this place and propping up another bakery to divert the flow of pastry lovers to a location where they'll find semi-bliss that they'll mistake for bliss using a vibrant orange safety vest and wands waving briskly, hypnotically. Just like my ex did who said, "It's me, Adom" - the perfect diversion. That's what a REAL pastry lover would and SHOULD do. 

But I have a defect where I need artisans to succeed wildly when they serve pastries this debilitating. Press pause on Paris, visit, with morning sun on your face, stuffed with exquisite pastry.
author: Adom K.

description:
I am obsessed with this place. I've had it bookmarked for almost 3 years and finally got the chance to go today, so I went crazy and tried 6 or so pastries. They have a huge variety of sweet and savory pastries/breads/cakes priced at roughly 3-5 dollars each. There might be a long line but it moves decently quickly so don't be daunted! 

Favorites from today: raspberry violet praline pastry & pistachio blackberry twice-baked. 

Everything is so amazing! The puff pastry is so crispy and flaky and there are just so many flavors to choose from. There's also a decent amount of outdoor seating so you can grab a pastry + coffee and relax outside. Overall possibly my favorite bakery in the city!
author: Melissa H.

description:
Wait - 5-10 minutes

Value - $5 / dish.

Dish Size: Medium

Everything Croissant - Flaky, buttery, but chewy on the inside is how a croissant should be. The Everything Croissant is the epitome of those characteristics plus the addition the everything seasoning on top. 

Pistachio Blackberry Twice-Baked - After having this, I'm set on believing that all pastries should be twice-baked. The outer layer is a nice crunchy mixture of pistachios and mashed blackberries. The inside, much like the croissant, is flaky, butter, but chewy inside. 


If you plan on heading to Neighbor Bakehouse, be on the lookout for the line snaking out onto the sidewalk. The line length is a bit misleading, as there is only a small ordering area for customers. Also, the line does move quickly as the Neighbor Bakehouse staff is efficient with the orders. Majority of the space is dedicated to their baking operations, therefore Neighbor Bakehouse does not offer any interior seating but has a handful of tables on their patio. 

Neighbor Bakehouse is one of those types of places where you leave questioning, "If pastries are supposed to taste like this, what have I been having my whole life?"
author: Julian L.

description:
Delicate and perfect pastries paired with a piping cup of coffee, woohoo! Love that this place is open early! 6:30am! 

Why I was here // I work nearby and sometimes I need to kickstart my mornings with a decent pastry and cuppa joe. 

Pastries // 
-pistachio blackberry // 4.50 // mouthwatering and delightful. The pistachio really gives the overall buttery pastry a nice kick to the tastebuds. 
-Ham and cheese morning bun // 4.50 // Really loved this! But maybe one for later in the day. Its rich and satisfying, I would love this as part f my lunch. 
-everything croissant // 3.75 // One of my faves! Topped with a tons of stuff and filled with everything, jk filled with a heavy blue cheese cream cheese filling. 

Overall // They have amazing pastries and are decently priced for the quality that you get! I probably come here about once a month to try something new, I would come more often, but 2018 goals keep me at bay.
author: Emily T.

description:
20 minute walk from our place, but the walk was worth it. They had so many selections of pastries. From sweet or savory. We had 2 morning buns, a passion fruit, and a regular croissant. The morning buns had ham and cheese and the flavors of the sesame seeds and sun flower seeds came out. 

The outdoor seating was nice too. Somewhat clean tables. Didn't mind the crumbs since the wind easily blew it away.

The cart with the napkins, lids, straws, etc were organized and clean.

I had to -1 star because I wanted a latte, but they only had either almond milk and whole milk. I'm lactose intolerant and I have anaphylactic allergy with all types of nuts. I had to do the whole milk, so now I'm suffering. 

They have a menu outside, but they have way more items that are not listed on the menu so before making up your mind outside, make sure you look at the goodies inside first.
author: Darlene M.

description:
They have 5 stars on Yelp...

I've tried to indulge here a few times, but they were closed.  They close at 2:00, & they're not open on Monday or Tuesday.

This, of course, only made me want them more.

So when I finally succeeded at a visit inside, the thrill of that victory alone was almost as satisfying as biting into one of their croissants.

Almost.

I don't usually eat an entire croissant by myself.  If & when this does happen, it is because I found a truly superlative product.

It happened here.  

I had no intention of eating the entire croissant myself.  We got a few items, to share.  But I really just couldn't help myself.  All of a sudden, it was gone.  The almond cinnamon bostock was nothing short of remarkable, either.  Think cinnamon roll, but lighter, w almond.  I believe I chose the best 2 things to couple w coffee.

Speaking of coffee...

What are the odds that a 5 star bakery will also carry 5 star coffee?  4 star coffee, all the time.  Even 4 & 1/2 star coffee.  But the 5/5 coffee to bakery ratio is more elusive.  Neighbor Bakehouse nails it.  Seriously, the De La Paz (which is roasted by Four Barrel) served here pairs better than Equator does w Bouchon.  No joke.

The best.

Another 5 stars.
author: Veronica M.

description:
The only reason I would trek to this side of town. & yes it was worth it.

SO many good options, come hungry, bring friends, share the love. 

favorites were: bostock & mushroom tart

the only one I wasn't a huge fan of was surprisingly the ham & cheese morning bun. had the everything mix sprinkled in, around, ALL over and had mustart. was too salty for my liking - everything else was delicious!
author: Kim N.

description:
I got there just before closing on a Sunday and while they didn't have too many things left, the line was at least very short!

I got the Muffaletta sandwich and a chocolate pudding bun and both were excellent! The bun was light and fluffy with chilled, creamy, gooey chocolate pudding inside. The Muffaletta bun was perfect and the meat and cheese on the sandwich were also flavorful.

Both items were a tad on the pricey side but they were decent-sized and of great quality and taste.

I definitely want to come back (and brave the line) and try more of the menu!
author: Jeffrey S.

description:
I've been to almost all of the "name" bakeries in the past couple months in the city and I must admit this place is up there. 

Located in the dogpatch , it provides great variety of dishes and good bang for your buck compared to some of the other spots. 

It took me awhile to decide what to get but I encourage you to try several of the items since two of the items that were essentially my "last picks" ended up being my faves. 

This is what I picked up (don't judge, LOL..I'm in the gym everday sucka!!) 

From fave to least fave:  Everything was good. 
1)Cinnamon Almond Bostock - This was delicious and I almost didn't snag it. Savory,moist 
2) Ham Cheese Morning Bun -  This also was suprisingly good. First couple bites I was going to toss it but it got better the closer you got to the center
3) chocolate chip cookie  - As the employee noted, this tastes the best fresh.  Super delicious choco cookie 
4) Pistachio Blackberry Twice Baked Croissant - The wifey really like this and it was good just 4th for my list 
5) Ginger Pullapart - Also very good but a clear # 5 for me 
6) Passion Fruit Doughp Bun  -  My wife liked this dish a lot but I'm not a big fan of fruits in baked items in general but it was pretty good as well.
I like lists what can I say? 

When I look at reviews sometimes just want to know where to go or how a user compares one venue against another to see if we have similar tastes. 

Here is a look at how I rank the SF Bakeries I've visited and I indicated what they're known for or a dish I recommend:

Rod's SF Bakery rankings (and what they're known for or what I like). ?) Follow my profile to see my most recent reviews I hope I can be helpful since so many Yelpers have helped me discover new places. 
1 Neighbor Bakehouse=cinammon almond bostock
2 B Patisserie=Choco Bannana croissant
3 Zanze's Cheesecake=Regular cheesecake
4 Ariscault =Croissant
5 Yasukochis=Coffee Crunch Cake
6 Chili Pies Baking Co=Pies

9 Mr Holmes Bakehouse=Green tea croissant ,Cruffin, 
10 La Luna Cupcakes=cupcakes
11 Three Babes Bakeshop=pies

13 New Hollywood Bakery=Egg tart
14 Dianda's Italian American Pastry=Napoleon , Cannoli
15 Mission Pies=Banana Cream Pie
16 Schubert=Swedish Princess cake

19 Craftsman & Wolves=Rebel within
20 Bob's Donut & Pastry Shop=any donut 
21 Noe Valley Bakery=dipped cupcake
22 Café Greco=Cannoli 
23 Kings Bakery=Tres leches cake

25 Cupcake cove=cupcakes
26 Cups and Cakes Bakery=cupcakes
27 Good Mong Kok Bakery=dim sum
28 Karas cupcake=cupcakes
29 Mission Minis=cupcakes

34 Panaderia La Mexicana=mexican sweet bread
35 Hot cookie=Cookies
36 Les Gourmands Bakery=Croissant
37 Mee Mee Bakery=Cow ears
author: Rod M.

description:
Spectacular! Delicious bakery in my new neighborhood. I normally don't like to eat all sugar and carbs for breakfast, but I'd make an exception for this place! I can't recall exactly what my pastries were called. One was something like raspberry violet hazelnut croissant, and the other one was a strawberry lemon shortcake of some sort, with mousse on top. Both were exotic and delicious, and cost less than $5 per item (I think). 

Came here on a Sunday morning and the wait wasn't too bad. The line was out the door, into the patio area, but it went by fast as they had 3 people at the register: one cashier, one barista, and one bagging the pastries. 

There is a patio area where you can eat outside. Since this is the Dogpatch, the weather is typically sunny and warm, so it's quite enjoyable. I highly recommend it! Note that it is closed on Mondays and Tuesday. Street parking also isn't too bad in this area.
author: Jennifer W.

description: Everything is good. We got a mushroom tart, double baked croissant w blackberry and pistachio. Great place for incredible pastries.
author: Lior T.

description:
I am NEVER going back to Tartine for my morning pastries now that I know Neighbor Bakehouse exists. It's everything I wanted in a weekend morning bakery: short lines that move quickly, plenty of outdoor picnic tables, and importantly, a unique pastry selection that tastes incredible. 

We ordered 6+ pastries (no regrets), and there was not a single one I didn't enjoy. Standouts that will be staples in future visits: Ginger pull apart bread, pistachio blackberry twice baked crossaint (my personal fav), and mushroom tart. 

I do wish it wasn't in the middle of nowhere, but it's right off the Muni line, and a bit of peace and quiet away from the crowds is nice. Also, there are a lot of really cute dogs!
author: Denise L.

description:
The blackberry pistachio croissant is to die for. I could eat them all day long. My husband thinks it's too sweet but I have a huge sweet tooth so it was perfect. I've also tried the ginger pull apart and I loved that too. Both pastries were crispy and buttery. I've been here several times and every single time, the pastries have been amazing. 

We also ordered coffee. The cold brew was too acidic for me but the latte was good.
author: Ang W.

description:
What's not to like? The line looked intimidatingly long, but orders are taken and made quickly. Staff was really friendly and seemed to all get along with each other too. 

I came on a Sunday at 1:45, and a lot of the pastries were already gone! There were some loaves of bread and croissants, but not much was left. The croissant was fine - nothing special. 

I ended up ordering a chai latte with oat milk just because I wanted to try oat milk. It was strange, but still hit the spot. 

Otherwise... not much else to say. There's an abundance of outdoor seating, so it's easy to find a spot to sit and catch up with friends.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
This place has really good pastries! My boyfriend and I stopped by here for a small breakfast! We ordered the Croque Madame and Smoked Fish Cream Cheese Croissant. 

The Smoked Fish Cream Cheese Croissant was so good! It was very light, the croissant was flaky and airy, and it was not too heavy at all. I wish I ordered another one of these! The Croque Madame was excellent! I never had this before but the egg on top definitely hit the spot!

The store is pretty small and you just lineup and order to go with a few tables outside. I would definitely come more often if I was closer and definitely hope I am able to come again soon! There aren't many bakeries like this near my work/home!
author: Allie Y.

description:
I was super excited to come here because this place has 5 stars on yelp! 

I was thoroughly disappointed. We ordered three things: ginger pull-apart, pistachio blackberry croissant and the chocolate pudding doughp bun. 

The ginger pull apart and pistachio blackberry croissant were very cold, dense and not as soft, flaky and crisp as I thought they would be. As my boyfriend said "the pastries at Costco are softer." Would I come back here? Nah. 

Arsicault Bakery in the inner Richmond is soooo much better.
author: Tran N.

description:
Neighbor Bakehouse was almost like a mirage gleaming in the distance after walking an hour to get there from the Financial District (my mistake as I thought it looked way, way closer on the map).  With that being said, my fiance and I were a little grumpy from getting sun-burned on our walk over - I tried not to let that grumpiness impede the delightful pastries.  Instead, I tried to turn my frown upside down, and address this mirage as what it was: a treat, a savior at long last!  And it was a savior - it killed the hunger in my stomach, but I still cannot make myself give Neighbor Bakehouse more than a 3.5 star review.

Here's why.  I loved the sweet pastries, and I think I would be a fool if I did not.  However, the savory pastries were less of an attraction to me.  I know the talk around town is that the kouign ahmans here are on a need-to-buy-basis, but I probably could have done without them.  I ordered the ham and cheese one, and yes it was good, but I wasn't swooning.  We also got tbe croque madame which tasted nothing like the real thing.  Besides this, it was cold amd the flavor was completely off.

The sweet pastries, though.  Mmmm, those are scrumptious.  While we enjoyed the savory pastries on the cafe's outside seating we actually nibbled at these goodies while sipping on some beer at the Anchor Brew Tour.  We had tbe blackberry pistachio pastry allng with the almond bockstock - both were crazy doughy and sweet, but not overly sweet, not to mention both were doused in powdered sugar.  I looked (and felt) like Mrs. Clause after eating them.

So, I got 4 different pastries, but that added up to something outrageous...unless you don't think that $28 is a little ridiculous for pastries that are going to be eaten in a manner of minutes.  I'm all for supporting local businesses, but it makes it hard to do when it's so expensive, and I only loved half the items I got.  Part of the reason that the savory pastries weren't as good were because they were sitting out for however many hours.  They didn't seem as fresh, and that was probably the biggest downfall for me.  It seems that yes, the items may not sit out for  too long as people are lined up out the door (partly because it is tiny inside) to buy them, but some of the items had clearly sat out for longer than others.
author: Lauren K.

description:
Went in for ONE pastry and a latte, left with three... 'nuf said. So glad I belong to a gym!

Oh had the ginger pull a part, kouign amann and one other.
author: Jira T.

description:
I ordered about 6 items today, and would give the food itself maybe 4 stars. Still ranks far behind B. Patisserie on my list. 

The twice baked pistachio croissant was flaky, but maybe too sweet for my liking. The mushroom tart was tasty, but I wish they could heat it up. The ginger pull apart was surprisingly good - especially since I'm not the biggest fan of ginger! 

Minus 1 star, but maybe I should minus 2 stars because when I checked my receipt from Square (after I got home) I saw that I was charged for 2 guava cheese pastries when I only bought one. Maybe it was an honest mistake since I bought so many items? But really, they should ask how many I got if they couldn't see? 

I asked for a receipt because I needed to split the cost, but they didn't print paper receipts so I couldn't check on the spot there, and didn't look closely at the square receipt until I got home :(.

It's a shame that this has left such a bitter feeling in my mouth when I've been dying to try this place for so long. I hope that this is not something they do intentionally when customers order a lot of pastries. :(

If there's a community manager for the yelp page for Neighbor's, I'd appreciate if you could help me to fix this issue?
author: Cynthia X.

description:
I had a training at the LUX-SF building next door and wanted a place to grab a snack. With such glowing reviews, I knew I had to check Neighbors Bakehouse. 

The shop is cozy and has all their baked goodies displayed on a rack. They offer De La Paz coffee as well. 

The Apricot Jam Oatbar is delectable, and highly recommended! I also snagged a pull apart ginger bread and a raspberry hazelnut croissant to share later. 

Overall I paid $12 for three massive pastries. Not too shabby, and a nice change from Tartine. If I worked in the area, I'd definitely be here more often.
author: Heather N.

description:
My top two favorites were the cinnamon almond bostock and the pistachio blackberry twice-baked. I was most excited to try the bostock- which comes in a pretty fair size, very thick and dense. For the price, it exceeded my expectations and didn't disappoint. I'm not a huge fan of croissants unless they are stuffed or there's just something special about it. But, this one has got to be the best I've had/ in a long time. The pistachio and blackberry compliment one another and it's a pretty heavy pastry, but the flavors are unique combination which make it really good. 

The runner- up is the passionfruit doughp bun, which we ate last because I knew the passionfruit flavor would be on the stronger side and take away our taste buds from everything else. The filling ratio was the perfect amount, right amount of tartness and something more on the tropical side (different from the other pastries they offer). 

Tried the guava & cream cheese pastelito, which didn't really amaze me too much. There wasn't enough filling and I would probably prefer the one offered at Porto's in LA.

The only savory item we tried was the curry potato turnover, the flavor was bland. even when the worker recommended this one over the mushroom tart, but I was disappointed in this one. Probably my least favorite.
author: Audrey K.

description:
I'm not a pastry-for-breakfast person. I usually find them too sweet and not worth the calories, so didn't have high hopes when my brother recommended this place. Boy, was I wrong. Everything we tried was delish. 
- Sauerkraut, smoked cheddar, and peppadew tart ($3.75)- this was the unanimous favorite. Gone so quick I didn't even have time for a pic. It sounds like a crazy combo, but was delish.
- Kimchee toast ($6)- thick slice of bread with some sort of creamy cheese, mild kimchee, and melted cheese on top. Genius! I want to try to make this at home with a spicier kimchee.
- Smoked fish and cream cheese croissant ($4.50)- not my fave filling, but the croissant pastry itself was as light as air, so good!
- cinnamon almond bostock ($4.50)- it looks like a slice of thick toast, but pulls apart like a cinnamon bun. Topped with crunchy almonds and just sweet enough. This was great!

There is a line, but it moves quick. Only seating is at the outdoor tables, so dress for the weather or get it to go. Bring a friend (or 2) so you can order a bunch of things to share. Def recommend.
author: Ryen B.

description:
Why are there always awesome bakeries next to the gyms I go to?  Went at 9am on a Sunday and barely had to wait.  By 10am the line is humongous.


---- SWEET ----

Chocolate Chunk Cookie:  4 stars
These are the crispy kind, not the soft chewy kind.  Crunchy texture and the flavour are wonderful.

Ginger Pull-Apart:  3.75 stars
This is very good bread, a crispy "muffin top" with softer inner layers but not much ginger flavour.  Get this if you pretty much want a plain brioche bun.

Chocolate Pudding Doughp Bun:  2.5 stars
Bun is too dry, and the chocolate cream inside is nothing special.


---- SAVOURY ----

Mushroom Tart: 4.5 stars
Their puff pastry has attained perfection.  I should def try their croissants sometime.
author: Letitia L.

description:
Yas, everything about everything is amazing here. Dare I even say, it's better than Tartine, Mr. Holmes, and Janes Bakery in the city...(well, it is)...

I'm pretty sure I've tried just about every single pastry that I possibly could (minus the meat ones), and my goodness are they the perfect savory or sweet snacks!! Or meals!! Whatever you want them to be!!

My only wish is that this place would be closer to me...sad, right? Or not sad haha... But seriously, parking's a little tougher around here, unless you're willing to walk. The blocks in the Dogpatch area are longgggg blocks. So get ready to work a little for these little gems. Benches/tables out in front to catch some rays while chowing down.

My favs are the ginger pull, twice baked (anything and everything), mushroom croissant tart (ah! so good!), and passion fruit bun. Lines here are 100x less crazy than any other bakery in SF. Seriously, prob bc the tourists have never heard of the Dogpatch (or anything past the ballpark). Def more locals hanging around this spot. 

Easily, easilyyyy 5 stars!
author: Jennifer L.

description:
If I were to recommend any bakery in SF, Neighbor bakehouse would be one  of the  first to  come out of my mouth. The pastries are flavorful and CRISPY, which is really important for me when it comes to bread. It's also nice and soft where it needs to be. I had a chocolate croissant which was warm, buttery and crispy, and soft on the inside. Omg it was amazing. I've been a few times and tried a bunch of things like the pistachio bread.... Chocolate croissant... Passion fruit... All great. I was even more fortunate to come when it was closed and brought a few friends... they so happened to be there baking. They could probably see my sad face in the window and came out with a few pastries for me and 2 for my friends. So nice !! Really, it made my day. I just wish they had longer hours.

In conclusion: I honestly love this shop. GET EVERYTHING.
author: Lyra C.

description: Was told off by the curly haired female staff with glasses for taking photos. Oh wait, there's no sign anywhere that says no photos. And it's a place that serves food and even though people have mixed opinions on whether one should take photos of food, many do it, so it's more or less "normal" these days? Was she worried about potential competitors trying to spy on them? Oh actually, Neighbor's own instagram has photos and videos of their baked goods and their kitchen ‍ I wasn't blocking traffic either because it was a Wednesday at 7:20am and we were the only people inside - so what is it? I have tried most of their stuff and everything is mediocre (subjective statement of course - evacuated based on my preferences) except for the raspberry hazelnut croissant (and second place: pistachio blackberry croissant). Those are so good. Most negative reviews on google and yelp are about their customer service. It's true that the customer service has never been overwhelmingly positive but it was never much of a problem because it was never technically bad - their staff are just like every waiter in France who doesn't work for tips - kind of condescending and/or not giving a damn but still overall reasonably efficient. The curly haired woman with glasses though - I saw a yelp reviewer who was said to frequent the place weekly and wrote that the service is bad  but she was especially bad and needed an attitude check ‍ not working for tip is not inherently an excuse to be rude though - servers in Australia don't work on tip but the majority of them are super friendly. I'll just go to Bluestone lane coffee shop in the city that serves their raspberry hazelnut croissant in the future (and much better coffee). And if I reeeeaaally want the pistachio hazelnut for a change, I'll call ahead and make sure she's not working
author: Weich Y.

description: Got the pistachio blackberry twice baked  it was warm when i got it and i couldn't wait to eat it fresh!  Definitely a huge win, nice and flakey on the outside and warm with filling inside. Would def get this again. Since its sprinkled with powder sugar you have to eat it fast or it can get soggy in the bag.
author: Melanie T.

description:
FIVE STARS!!!

I've had Neighbor Bakehouse bookmarked for FOREVER, but I knew I would never make it to this area in the mornings since it's so out of the way from where I live. 

But then the stars aligned and it happened. I had to drop the BF off for work at 7am, so we got up earlier so we could swing by and grab a few items for breakfast....AT 6:30AM. 

I honestly thought it wouldn't be busy since it was so early, WRONG. After we ordered, there was a line out the door! 

Everything sounded delicious, but I decided to narrow our items to 4 pastries. Unfortunately, some of the items weren't ready yet (really wanted to try the mushroom tart!) 

We got the sauerkraut tart, smoked fish croissant, pistachio blackberry twice baked, and BF really wanted to bring the potato and chorizo tart with him to work. He also got a cold brew coffee. 

The good thing about coming right when they open is that everything is warm and fresh!! 

Sauerkraut tart: really good! I was apprehensive that this would have an overwhelming sauerkraut taste, which I don't mind, but it didn't at all. It's also very substantial so 1 would be perfect for a quick breakfast! 

Smoked fish croissant: the croissant comes covered with sesame seeds which I enjoyed. Its very flaky and light, and the smoked fish with cream cheese wasn't overpowering for the morning. However, I think this was my least favorite (not that it wasn't good, I just thought this one didn't shine like the rest) 

Pistachio blackberry twice baked: THIS IS WHAT DREAMS ARE MADE OF. SOOOOO GOOOOOOOOD. We didn't eat this till a lot later in the day, and it was amazing, so I can imagine eating it fresh out of the oven would be an out of body experience. MUST GET. 

Potato chorizo tart: I had a small bite. It was good! Hefty. But BF ate the rest of it for a late breakfast and said it was just as good cold. He really enjoyed it. 

The cold brew was actually nitro coffee, which was good. 

Service was friendly and quick! 

If you're in the area and can get here early, this is a must visit to get your carb fix!!!
author: Noelle H.

description:
Neighbor bakehouse is my personal favorite Western bakery in SF, especially in the Eastern part. IMO it's highly underrated. Neighbor consistently serves high quality "artisanal" bread without as much hype as places such as Tartine. I always come through here on the weekend to get my bread fix. They serve loaves, savory pastries and sweet pastries.  Breads are priced pretty high, but inline with other high-tier bakeries (or just SF). The menu changes from time to time and they run out of breads by the end of the shift. 

Located in dogpatch, it's a lowkey bakery with some seating outside. Lines vary between no line to 20m lines.

I've ordered (* is a favorite)
* Smoked fish cream cheese croissant 
* Raspberry violet twice-baked
* Pistachio blackberry twice-baked
* Potato curry with chorizo turnover
Ginger pull-apart
Cinnamon almond bostock
Buckwheat orange financier
Vege pizza
Coffee cake
Everything croissant
author: Sean W.

description:
I came here because I typed in "kouign amann" into yelp and this place popped up. So I go in there and ask for one and the worker was like "what?" with the most confused look on his face lol! I realized they clearly do not sell kouign amanns. I asked what the worker's favorite pastry was and he suggested the passion fruit "doughp" bun. Yup. Dough with a "p" at the end so that you pronounce it "dope". Cute pun huh? It's like a croissant filled with passion fruit creme for $4. It was flaky, spot on in flavor, and baked just right. It tasted like I was eating an island of Hawaii lol. You must try this! 

Anyways now that I'm home, I researched the yelp reviews for this bakery with the search word "kouign amann". It turns out, the have a pastry that's similar to kouign amanns. It's their ginger pull apart bread. I'll have to give it a try next time.
author: Lexi R.

description:
My 12 year old daughter has to eat gluten free. Got into the city this morning early to see the Carnaval parade and looked in yelp for a gluten free bakery. 

Made our way to your bakery. She had a gf muffin and we got a gf macaroon for a snack later on. It's been over a year that she has to eat GF and she rarely gets a baked good treat since GF friendly bakeries in our neck of the woods aren't so common. 

I'd totally recommend this place if you too are GF and in the city!
author: Kelly G.

description: Nice neighborhood bakery with friendly staff. One person ahead of us on a Saturday morning (8am) but a line quickly developed. Come for the cinnamon almond Bostock (5/5)! You won't regret it. Ordered other goodies including the butter croissant, twice baked blueberry pistachio croissant, and ham & gruyere bun.
author: Amy H.

description:
YUM!!

My bf and I love coming here. We love all the pastries options and everything looks so good and fresh. Yes it does smell like actual baking here. I love the workers too they're all very urban and friendly. The bakery itself it pretty quaint and yes like all great places there will be a line. Not a ridiculous line more like a like wait time before devouring your purchases. Which you can conveniently do outside on the cute community benches. 

So far the bf and I have had both the chocolate and passion fruit buns, the passion fruit macaroon and the bear claw. Though we definitely plan on getting the many other selections and all the savory items. Croque madame *be still my heart*. I love that the pastries actually taste like what their flavor is. It does taste like passion fruit.

Tip: They are in a shared lot area so yes there will be street parking and no you will not find it close. BUT yes it's definitely worth it. My bf and I tend to park near 20th and Indiana. Not bad of a walk, may i say again totally worth it. It's infinity times better than Mr. Holmes.
author: Denice D.

description: WOAH. I've had a lot of pastries in my life. They're my favorite and I schedule my day around eating all the best, all around the world. And these are incredible. I can't believe it took me so long to try this place, but I'll be back often and bring all those people I love. With only two people, we could only try three things: pistachio blackberry croissant, ginger pull apart and the savory ham and cheese morning bun. All AMAZING. Really so good! The pull apart was so delicious, with cinnamon and ginger that was perfectly complementary and not overpowering. Loved the pistachio flavor of the croissant and the slightly tart pop of blackberry. My greatest regret is not ordering more. Dear bostock and raspberry hazelnut croissant, it's not goodbye, it's see you later.
author: Madeline S.

description:
Reviews didn't lie. Super amazing stuff. Line moved quick. All in all super good. 

Very crispy croissants. Cooked beautifully
author: Ross K.

description: just come here and get everything. It's so so good. we live in the nabe and understand the hype.
author: Angela H.

description:
This place is so good. My friend lives in Dogpatch and recommended we grab some pastries for our flight home.....so I did. I went in there and pointed at random items that sounded good. I ended up with:

Smoked salmon cream cheese croissant - something like that, don't remember exactly --- all I remember was that it was flaky exterior, tasty, creamy interior. Could've used a touch more smoked salmon, but meh.

Ham and cheese morning bun - ratio of ham and cheese not so great, most of the croissant was hollow...but can't argue with how perfect the croissant was; flaky and buttery, the perfect complement to the salty ham and cheese

Everything croissant - exactly what you'd expect, executed perfectly. The flaky croissant topped with the everything seasoning. Love my savory pastries. 

Cinnamon almond bostock - I would never order this based on the name (just doesn't sound appealing to me), but thanks to Yelp highlights, I went for it and it was easily my favorite item on the list. Sweet, slightly crispy exterior. 

I ate 1 pastry per day for the next week! Popped it in the toaster oven at work...and they were all still good......comparable to when I had it freshly baked. 

Everyone was friendly and I didn't feel rushed when I was deciding. A little on the pricey side for a baked good, but well worth the quality and freshness.
author: Lisa N.

description:
SO YUMMY!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
One of the rare places where you can't go wrong with what you order. On weekdays, the lines are pretty short, and on weekends, they can get pretty long (one Saturday morning, I came ~10am and waited about 20 mins in line). I tried a lot of the pastries, and I think my favorites are the ginger pull-apart, blackberry pistachio twice baked croissant, and mushroom tart. My first time here, I didn't think I was going to finish my two pastries, but I inhaled everything... which means 1) the pastries are the perfect amount of sweet (not overwhelming and you don't feel gross after) and 2) they were sooooooooooooooo delicious that I felt zero guilt for eating two pastries as my first meal of the day after boxing class.
Conveniently (or dangerously) located a block away from my boxing gym (and dogpatch boulders). I'll definitely be introducing my friends to this place whenever I can!
No indoor seating and it's getting cold these days so bundle up if you're going to eat at one of the tables outside!!
author: Annie S.

description:
I love unexpectedly discovering amazing places! 

Sarah K. and I stumbled upon Neighbor Bakehouse while we were looking for a place to kill some time before our brunch reservation. We've always talked about checking out some SF bakeries one day like Tartine so it was such a coincidence that Neighbor Bakehouse is ex-Tartine's Greg Mindel's (which I found out just now thanks to Yelpers). 

I couldn't help but get a lot of stuff to sample, aka take a few bites and 'gift' the rest to my housemates, heh. 

+ smoked fish cream cheese croissant - $4.25
+ mushroom green onion tart - $4.00
+ pistachio blackberry twice baked croissant - $4.25
+ apple cinnamon hand pie - $3.75

My favorite was the pistachio croissant which was perfectly flakey with just the right hint of flavors. Mmm, delicious. 

So so so many goodies here - I want to try them all!
author: Laverne N.

description:
While it probably benefits just a tad inordinately by being one of the few good bakeries in its immediate vicinity, there's no denying that Neighbor turns out lots of good stuff. Savory items like the ham and cheese morning bun were just as satisfying as you'd expect, and there are lots of sinfully sweet baked goods like cookies and pastries that you'll enjoy too.

Service was fairly decent, and the only thing I'd recommend is to get here earlier in the day than later. A nice addition to the neighborhood.
author: Vincent L.

description:
I've had their butter croissant, pistachio blueberry, and apple hazelnut pastries. Amazing. Great outer crisp that isn't too flakey or hard. The inside is buttery soft and not too airy. The pistachio blueberry had real pistachios on top of a cookie(?) that was on top of the flakey danish-like bottom (I don't know my pastries so this is the best I can do to). The bottom part is similar to the croissant but filled with some filling--nothing oozy, just delicious paste-like blueberry jam/pistachio mix. Anyway, I don't think I'm going to try and describe the apple hazelnut because I've already struggled with the pistachio blueberry, but it's basically the same thing with nuts on the top and jam filling inside.

Love that the sweetness is not overpowering and how the textures come together. Can't wait to try everything on the menu eventually--especially their savory items.
author: Lydia Z.

description:
930AM, line out the door, but moved really quick. 
Graciously enjoyed my salmon croissant, and everything croissant. They were both extremely crispy, fresh, and flaky. Amazing filling inside. Prices were more than fair. Why can't San Diego have croissants this amazing?? Also ordered a latte, which was quite delicious as well. Outside seating area was nice. I wanted to come back here to take some croissants home, but I was too late the day I left :(
author: Sam V.

description:
Food:

So I bought the pistachio blackberry croissant as well as the cherry hazelnut croissant baked goods and the funny thing is that they actually tasted very similar.  A very good choice of flavors but I'd like to taste a little more of distinction between the two.

Service: nice friendly staff.

Ambiance: just your local neighborhood bakery.  Line went out the door but it's a fairly small line.

Overall: given the different flavor combinations I'd come again to try something new.
author: Spencer Q.

description:
Ugh, how I wish I lived in San Francisco... I'd move there just to eat here every morning.

This place is a dream come true. Every single pastry I tried here was absolutely delicious -- flaky, buttery, rich, salty, sweet, etc. My favorites were the everything croissant, mushroom pastry, and the ginger pull-apart. However, I would whole-heartedly recommend anything on the menu.

You shouldn't be too taken aback by the line in front of Neighbor Bakehouse. First of all, the long line means the food is AMAZING. Second of all, the line moves very quickly! At the same time, once you start ordering, the workers don't rush you; they are really patient and willing to help you pick out items. 

Definitely visit this place if you have the chance. Order a box of pastries, and sit outside. Enjoy!
author: Nini N.

description:
I have been eating my favorite passion fruit donut for years. However, it was so disappointed today. The donut was a bit dry. The passion fruit filing was icy cold like you just pulled out from the fridge or left it in the cold kitchen overnight. 

For consistency, I suggest everyone goes to Arsicault Bakery in Richmond.
author: J L.

description:
Neighbor Bakehouse was the first bakery I visited in SF since moving back to the west coast from the east coast.

I love how serious Bay Area folks are about their pastries. Everything we ordered was delicious and exceeded expectations.

We lined up around around noon on a Saturday and waited in line for about thirty minutes. 

All the pastries/croissants were amazing. They would be even more amazing if they were served hot or toasted. 

We also ordered a savory item that was like a croque monseiur. It had a surprising amount of onion in it - I liked it though. I requested them to toast it up. It was the only item that I had the nerve to ask them to toast. It was nice and warm. I have yet to try some other new bakeries that have opened up in SF since I last lived in the Bay Area, but I think Neighbor Bakehouse has to be one of the top five. 

They have a carafe of water and water glasses outside.

For parking, we parked around the corner (around the back/east side) of the building for free. We did have to circle around a bit to find a spot.  

That whole area is full of warehouses and is not completely gentrified yet, so woohoo for free parking. 

Afterwards, we stopped by Mr. and Mrs. Miscellaneous for some ice cream. I probably should have saved the pastries and brought them over to Mr. and Mrs. to eat with ice cream.
author: Thien H.

description: Best baked goods in SF.   Croissants with a twist.   Very buttery, flakey and incredible flavor.   The staff is friendly, helpful and outdoor seating.  The owner and his wife run a great business.   Annabelle at the counter is very friendly and had excellent customer service.  A must stop for baked goods!!!!
author: Michael C.

description: We stopped by (based on Yelp reviews) when visiting from out of town, and it was worth a stop, but not somewhere I would visit frequently if I lived in the area.  My family tried four of their items, and everything was good, but nothing blew me away.  Some of their items didn't have prices or labels and customers move through the very small space quickly, so I felt pressured to decide quickly to avoid holding up the line.
author: Emily B.

description:
i was in search for a new bakery shop so i decided to check this place out since it was recommended by someone. i came here on a saturday around10:45AM. i waited in line for about 20 minutes before i could place my order. i ended up ordering:

pistachio blackberry twice-baked (5/5) - would recommend this if you like berries
violet raspberry twice-baked (5/5) - also would recommend this if you like berries
guava and cream cheese pastelito (5/5) - have you ever had those guava & cream cheese strudels at Porto's Bakery? if so, then it's almost the same. would also recommend this
chocolate claw (4/5) - this is pretty chocolatey, very similar to the chocolate croissants at Starbucks. would recommend if you're a chocolate lover
everything croissant (5/5) - this is like the everything bagel, but croissant. there's cream cheese inside the croissant

i liked the pastries i ordered, but i'm sad that they ran out of the ham & cheese morning bun and the mushroom tart. i'll have to come back here at an early time!

there's an open seating area outside the shop for you to enjoy your pastries since it's a small bakery shop.
author: Sylvia H.

description: Yum! I still had room for more yumminess after brunch at nearby Serpentine. When my friend mentioned a hip new bakery nearby, I knew we had to stop by. We snuck in the door 5 min before 2 when they close on Saturday, and we were happy that the lines had dissipated by then. Luckily for us, they still had many tasty treats on the shelves. I couldn't help myself from getting the chocolate pudding pie which was a massive quarter pie sized slice. I also snagged a chocolate croissant. Two treats for $11 isn't cheap, but this was some really high quality stuff! My chocolate pudding pie was gorgeous, topped with marshmallow looking clouds of piped cream sprinkled with chocolate shavings. The chocolate pudding was rich without being too sweet. My favorite part was definitely the puff pastry crust. And there was even a layer of caramel between the crust and the pudding. Maybe to prevent sogginess from setting in? I don't quite know but it was a delicious surprise! This was a slice perfect for sharing and all 5 of the people I shared bites with gave it top marks. My croissant held up pretty well even into the next day. And to top off the experience, when my sister went inside to throw some trash away, one of the staff gave her a chocolate button bun for free as they hadn't sold it but the store was about to close! I already love this place and will definitely stop by next time I'm in Dogpatch.
author: Leslie H.

description:
I bought two loaves of bread (walnut sourdough and country sourdough) and the pear, persimmon, ginger, black sesame crumble pie. All items were good. However the bread was not sour (although good tasting and great texture) and the pie had no persimmon nor black sesame flavors. It was all pear and ginger flavor. The crust and crumble top were good. 

I definitely wouldn't buy their sourdough if you like your sourdough bread sour. (I typically order from Tartine and thought I'd try Neighbor's bread). I think they should keep the pie flavors simple by separating the pie flavors i.e. pear and ginger pie and persimmon and black sesame pie.
author: Michael C.

description:
You'll be in a long line (most likely), so think about what you want to order in advance. Here's my take:
--Bostocks are nice to try once. The one I tried was slightly bland though, just slightly.
Tartines are 3/5. Too hard to eat.
-Ginger pullapart texture is too hard for my tastes, but I know everyone else loves it. I think if it were softer, more tender, I would enjoy as well as I love sugary ginger flavors.
-Croissants aren't too buttery, so they're okay, not as good as Tartine's. Perhaps 3.5/5.
-Chorizo potato turnover-thing is 2/5, did not like it. It was like a cold hot pocket. The mashed potato texture was not pleasant.
-Chocolate croissants are flaky and indulgent, definitely get.
-Morning buns are yummy, and I love the poppy seeds and sesame seeds galore.

Best to reheat the treats so they're eaten warm.
