Each treat is $4-$8.50 appx. So bills can get pricey! I tend to spend $30 each visit.

Line is too long for me on weekends; I don't think I can bear 30 mins in line only to see what I want has run out. They tend to run out of the good stuff on weekends by 10:00am! NB staff, please adjust what you prepare for demand, so you don't run out on them faves. Please and thank you.

Love the outdoor seating (all shaded), with doggies and babies all around (more babies than doggies); there is no indoor seating.
author: Sarah W.

description:
A SF trip can never be complete without a visit of local, renowned bakery. Neighbor Bakehouse has long been on my Must Visit list, so I was so excited that I had a chance to visit. We drove there around 8 in the morning. It's quite easy to find a parking spot on the street. Luckily, there's no line, and the aroma of those buttery pastries just is satisfying and enticing. There are only some tables outside, so we decided to order togo. We ended up buying nine baked goods, yogurt parfait, and some coffee.
The Food:
Everything Croissant: I didn't realize that there is cream cheese filling inside until my friend bit into it... she preferred a regular croissant. nonetheless, she loved it. 
Ginger Pull-Apart: first of all, this goodness is huge! I could easily share half of it with my friends. The flavor and texture are heavenly delicious, a hint of ginger with flaky, crispy dough. A must please!
Smoked Fish Croissant: this Cali infused croissant is unexpectedly amazing! The cream cheese mixed in smoked salmon and a touch of dill, a supreme lox croissant is served. 
Smoked Ham and Cheese Morning Bun: this is definitely not your average morning bun. Classic combination but elevated in both flavors and textures.
Yogurt Parfait: I can't let a day go without a bowl of yogurt. I wonder why their yogurt is so creamy and rich. The house made granola just made my morning even more enjoyable.
Even though they are pastries, but they aren't greasy or overly sweet. I can see why they maintain hundreds of five-star reviews.
author: Jui Han Y.

description: This place is HEAVEN!! Woke up early one Saturday morning and drove over to see a line about 20 deep. They have tables and benches right outside and saw some folks enjoying the scrumptious goodies. At that point I decided I needed ONE OF EVERYTHING! The GINGER PULL APART and the PISTACHIO BLACKBERRY TWICE BAKED CROISSANT changed my life forever!!! We also had a savory Croque that was amazing. I also wanted to get the kouign amman but they didn't have it that day. Ginger Pull Apart was gingerly and sticky with the perfect texture and consistency. The twice baked croissant tasted twice as good for a regular croissant. Definitely want to come back and try everything else next time. I might need to move back to the bay area just for this!!!! The line may look intimidating when you see it but it moves pretty quick and service is friendly!
author: Sylvia L.

description: Initially, I didn't think the wait in line would be worth the pastries, but I was so wrong (the wait wasn't actually very long, I'm just being dramatic)! We got a few things to try and they were just so delicious. Of the few things that we tried, none were too excessively sweet or too doughy - they were just right! The prices for each of the pastries were perfectly priced. My favorite was the ginger pull apart, thinking about it now is making me hungry. The seating is outside and is dog friendly which is perfect. Try it!
author: Nesha P.

description:
OMG!  Delicious savory and sweet treats, courteous staff who remembers regulars name, smaller lines than Tartine (Morning Bun is second to none) and your establishment adds a little brightness to the Potrero neighborhood (I don't care if they call it Dogpatch now...).  Thank you for your service!

My only critique, PLEASE add more smoked trout to that one croissant.  Other than that, muy bueno.
author: Venney B.

description:
Neighbor Bakehouse has some fantastic baked goods, but it's not without imperfections. My favorite of the pastries I tried was the pistachio blackberry twice baked. It was pretty decadent for a croissant- buttery, flaky, and definitely satisfies my sweet tooth. The ginger pull-apart was similar to a Kouign Amann, enjoyable but B. Patisserie's version is so good, everything else pales in comparison. I am forever ruined. 

The passion fruit doughp bun was really disappointing. It's only now that I type this out that I realize the intent behind the spelling. Dough + p = dope! Major points for the name, but the taste was not dope. The brioche bun was dry, and it took 5 bites of dough before I got to any filling. The passion fruit curd was a tad too sour, and I generally love tart desserts. I wish I'd gotten the cinnamon almond bostock instead. This was a complete waste of calories and money.

I think I'd still rather wait in the long line at Tartine.
author: Karen S.

description: Neighbor's is great, arguably the best bakery in San Francisco. It can get a little busy on weekends, but overall a great spot in the dogpatch. The savory morning bun is heavenly, and great cappuccinos!
author: Wilson L.

description:
Great bakers aren't born, they're bread. And Neighbor Bakehouse is no different especially when it comes to their fantastic team of bakers and pastry chefs. Needless to say, if you're ever in the Dogpatch area this is a MUST visit for all carb-lovers! They're great at turning your average stale day into a butter day! 

My to go favorites:
- Guava and cream cheese pastelito 
- Cinnamon Almond Bostock

Note: Always remember to ask the staff about their favorites.
author: Benson M.

description: They were out of half the items on the menu (posted on their window ) at 10am!! I had the bacon, potato turnover.  It was cold and did not taste fresh at all.   The cappuccino was nice though.
author: Marty M.

description:
I was pretty skeptical about trying this place out. We wanted to pick up some baked goods for a party we were going to and it was either here or Mr. Holmes. Mr. Holmes was sold out of a lot of items so we headed to Neighbor Bakehouse and man are we glad we did. There was a big line outside on Sunday morning around 11am. It took us about 20-25 minutes to get to the counter. We ordered:

Pistachio blackberry croissants
Cinnamon almond bostock 
Chocolate claw 
Ginger pull aparts
Sauerkraut smoked cheddar peppadew tart

Personally, I only tried the pistachio croissant and the cinnamon almond bostock. But they were SO good. The croissant was flaky and moist with the perfect amount of pistachio flavoring and the bostock was flavorful with a delicious crust. I didn't try the other items but man, the pastries were the hit of the party and they went quick! Their pastries range from $3-$7ish, which sounds ridiculous but it is worth it once you take that first bite. 

Parking in this area alright, better than most other parts of SF. We also loved how there were plenty of seats outside that are dog friendly. Lastly, 5 stars for their hipster vibe. 

We will definitely be back!
author: Ashley W.

description: This place is so good! Pistachio blackberry twice baked croissant and ginger pull apart were my favorites. Came around 30 minutes before closing and there was still a line of people trying to get whatever baked goods they had left. Definitely coming back.
author: Jeana Y.

description:
Butter Croissant #39 on the 2016 7x7 100 Things to Eat Before You Die list.

I finally made it to Neighbor Bakehouse during a Thursday afternoon since I was off of work. They were already sold out of a bunch of items, such as a financier, doughp flavor, and others, but there was still a good selection to choose from. There was only a short wait, and I ended up trying:

From L to R: Pistachio Blackberry Twice Baked Croissant ($4.25), Butter Croissant ($3), Lemon Lime Doughp Bun ($4) [http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=X32__i_R71WSgRXlEEmMkg&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg]

-Butter Croissant ($3): Yum- super buttery and flaky, this is one of the best versions I've had in a while- a must order! I can see why this is on the 7x7 list.
-Lemon Lime Doughp Bun ($4): Just ok, but I thought the lemon lime filling was too tart. I would try this again if it had another filling (like their chocolate pudding one) since the consistency of the doughp bun was interesting.
-Pistachio Blackberry Twice Baked Croissant ($4.25): Also delicious, and another must order! They do not skimp on the filling, and although the filling is plentiful, it isn't too sweet.

I will definitely be back to get more croissants, and also to try their other items and breads. Parking is the most difficult part about coming here since there are only a few spots in the tiny lot in front of the store, and there wasn't much available street parking to be found.
author: Amy D.

description:
Go on, try to find something you don't like. I dare you. (It's impossible). 

Check it: This little Dogpatch bakery is better than Tartine (sorry, but it's true). You cannot go wrong here. No choice is a bad choice. 

The lineup: 

Coffee: A+
Baked Goods:A+ 
Atmosphere: A+
The People: A++++++++++++

My favorite item: Ginger pull-apart - so decadent. 

I'm very lucky to live 1/2 block away and get ahead of the lines and I love the staff here; They are all such awesome humans. 

Thanks for sweetening up the neighborhood! 

Pro tip: Order one of their pumpkin pies around Thanksgiving, you won't regret it.
author: Jason L.

description: I was very impressed with both the quality and the prices of their pastries. Everything I tried was delightful! Chocolate croissant, pistachio blackberry twice bake, ham and cheese morning bun -- all superb.
author: Camille L.

description:
I've LOVE this place.

Order the pistachio blackberry twice baked croissant and thank me later :)

I've also had the ginger pull apart (the ginger flavor is strong, so you really have to like ginger to like this) and the butter croissant (a solid croissant).

The line can get long, but it moves along. It's a good thing this place is almost a mile and a half away because it forces me to either walk or run there and burn some calories before inhaling them all in again.
author: Leana L.

description:
freshly baked with extra butter for optimal flakiness. 

when i went here, I ordered the ginger pull-apart and the pistachio/blackberry croissant. I enjoyed them both. I think that I would have really benefited from trying the plain croissant to have a better baseline of what they offer. 

The ginger pull-apart bread was delicious. It was subtly spicy and have such a good bite. Texture is everything with me and I loved the texture of this bread. It's also a funny shape so that there are many bits that are risen for more crispiness since it's closer to the heat in the over. Definitely recommend this one. Bonus, it has little sugar crystals on the bottom. The sugar didn't make it overly sweet but definitely added crunch. 

The pistachio/blackberry croissant was sliced and filled with the blackberry and pistachio. It was also topped with a pistachio crumble and a had a powder sugar snow. I wouldn't say it was my favorite. It was a little too sweet for my taste (this is coming from a girl that like the smallest itty bit of jam on her toast). It's understandable for me. I did really like the croissant base and think that contributes to me wanting to try their plain one. Super buttery! I love that extra butter. making Paula Dean proud. 

Tip for parking: plenty of parking off of Third street, walk 4-6 blocks west and find yourself among the warehouse-ish looking buildings. Try to avoid the Aina crowd... Park far, you're going to do your body a favor by walking a bit of that butter off anyways. 

I would definitely recommend this place and look forward to coming back.
author: Tina Y.

description: This is probably my 7th time here! Keep coming back for the amazing pastries. My favorites are everything croissant, passion fruit doughbuns, curried potato turnover and then everything else is pretty awesome as well.  Coffee is pretty insane too. Lines move pretty fast, so don't get deterred! Lots of outside seating. Also, they usually have stuff outside of their menu as well - be prepared to make some last minutes decisions!
author: Namrata J.

description:
Wow! I'm in love with this bakery. First time here. We were an hour early for our lunch reservation at Aina. We wanted to walk around and check out the area. It was a beautiful, sunny, warm day. I'm so glad the hostess at Aina recommended Neighbor Bakehouse. 

Right when we walked in, the sweetness of bread and sugar aroma filled up the entire bakery. Small bakery. There was a line but it wasn't that bad. Everything looks so delicious and good. Due to the prices, I got two pastries only: raspberry croissant and ginger pull apart. Total was about $8. 

We sat on the bench outside and saw what other people had. Whatever they ordered, looks good too. I took my first bite out of the raspberry and ginger pull apart, and my taste buds were dancing! It was delicious. Flaky, buttery, sweet and fresh. Reminds me of a Paris. My husband ate all of the raspberry croissant and I got jealous. I wanted one for myself so had to get another to go. We spent $12 total for 3 pastries. Pricey. 

I wanted to get the everything croissant, ham and cheese, passion fruit, guava, pizza pastries, etc. Oh my!! I was drooling for all of them. Staff were friendly. Definitely coming back.
author: Amy H.

description:
One of the best bakeries in San Francisco located in the dogpatch. This place is a simple bakery with just a counter to order your baked goods and coffee. There is some outdoor seating which can get tight if they are busy. It's a neat set up as you can see the entire bakery/kitchen. Ordering is simple as they have their menu items and daily specials on display on racks out of the oven. The pastries are delicious and their bread is also very good. They have coffee/expresso but it's a simple set up as they put their focus on the baked goods. Service is friendly and efficient. It's a small space so there may be a line but they staff does a great job moving people through. 
To me their highlight is their croissants. They have different types from traditional butter, chocolate, and even an everything croissant a play on the everything bagel. So far everything I've tried here has been good and did not disappoint. 
What I love about their croissants is that they are so flaky and buttery and are perfectly baked. Every bite has that initial crispness when you bite in followed by the buttery chewiness inside. 
This place is a little out of the way but it's well worth the trip or a stop if you are in the area. Definitely plan on coming back and trying their other delicious looking goodies.
author: Peter P.

description: It is a small neighbor bake house with outside tables with viewing of downtown in the dog patches. Good quality pastries, coffee, portion size, made fresh daily and can taste fresh ingredients.Open space inside with display of the pastries and food served. Can see the baker making food from scratch. Staff are friendly and price are good. Would recommend this bakery if you love fresh cup of good coffee and pastries made fresh daily. Would come back again.
author: Gruber T.

description: Probably the best baked goods I've ever had because of the unusual flavors and the perfect crispiness!  I haven't tried the savory items, simply because the sweets are so amazing and I don't get there enough.  My favorites:  The Passionfruit dough bun, ginger pull apart, pistachio blackberry roll and the cinnamon almond bostock.
author: Julia N.

description:
So we just discovered this place...And omg where have u been all my life... I'm still dreaming about the raspberry violet hazelnut thing (completely forgot the name... )But u will know what I'm talking about when u go or if u have been there... Long lines usually indicate good food... And believe me when I'm say long lines... But they do move fast... Except for those indecisive people who can't seem to know wat they want.. (we took about 2 of everything haha.)
Only bad thing is parking... We had a handicap parking spot so used that but if we hadn't i wouldn't know where to park. 
Overall i would go back for that luscious yummy bread... Drooling again
author: Frawlahyn S.

description:
This place is a nice little hidden gem in one of SFs quiet up and coming neighborhoods. I pass it all the time and was desperately in need of coffee so I decided to stop. At first I was all "ah fuck another normie tech hipster party" but once I got through the line and inside I could tell these cats know their shit (see pics). 
  I really enjoyed the latte and the cookie was delicious. I didn't really feel the "Croque madame on Spanish toast" I've had croque madame in Paris and I've had the "toasts" in Madrid (oo lala famcy me right?) and it's not really close to either.. smoked fish croissant was good. 
  Overall I like this place. I'll be back forsure.
 Factses:
- Eat-in and to-go
- Long lines but fast service
- Kinda pricey $$ but real quality
- Parkings kinda harsh
- Hip but friendly
- doggo friendly
- Vegetarian/Vegan options
- good for breakfast and lunch
- good for family's, couples, and forever aloners
author: Jason M.

description: Wow, so refreshing to wait in a relatively short line (15 mins) for an awesome bakery in the city! We had the ginger pull apart, everything croissant, pistachio blackberry twice baked, passion fruit doughp bun, smoked fish croissant and chocolate claw. Yes, I went a little bananas.  Pastries range about $3-4.50 each.  I'm more a savory person so definitely recommend the everything and smoked fish croissant. All the pastries had a nice, flaky texture. Minus one star because I still think it's a little pricey for pastries, but everything tasted pretty amazing. Parking can be a challenge in the area.
author: Selina T.

description:
Gosh, I have been thinking about this place ever since I finished the last bite of my ginger pull apart last Saturday! The pastries are perfectly crispy and soft, and the ginger pull apart really only had a hint of ginger to it (and I'm normally not a fan of ginger!). Oh man, sooo good. 

It seems like everyone I've talked to has a favorite here, whether it's the passion fruit "doughp" bun (thought it was OK), the mushroom tart, any of the savory treats, or the chocolate claw. 

I might have to make this place part of my weekly routine ...
author: Cal C.

description:
My favorite bakery in SF right now... awesome workers that actually look like they thoroughly enjoy working there, none of that snobby hipster attitude.  

So what's good here? Seriously everything!
author: Leeseuh K.

description:
I'm hesitant to add more good reviews for this place since it's the closest suuuper quality bakery to my place without tartine or mr Holmes-length lines

Each visit I've come here, they've had a few staples on hand and a rotating cast of well conceived and executed pastries. Their croissants, claws and morning buns are super flaky and buttery, and they tend to have an interesting range of sweet and savory pastries day to day. I will say what gives them an edge over my other favorite bakeries in the city is that they are fast to serve customers and as of yet, tend to not run out of all the goods early on.
author: Neal B.

description:
Ok HELLO EVERYTHING CROISSANT so nice to meet you, let's be friends forever. Cream cheese... inside a croissant?! Not as buttery as Arsicault but I love it just the same. Definitely one of the top pastry spots in San Francisco. 

Come with low expectations and get one of everything. Lots of savory and sweet options, my other favs were the morning bun and chocolate croissant. 

Only cons are for seating. There are a few picnic tables outside but this is a more of a grab it and go spot. Average price of $3-$4 so pretty SF standard. Coffee is pretty good as well. 

Love the everything croissant so much but dread the drive to the dog patch? They sell them at sightglass coffee in soma. You're welcome.
author: Steph D.

description: One of the best bakeries that I've been to as of late. Great place to grab coffee and the pastries are amazing -- got the chocolate beignet thing and the red pepper croissant.l, which is both sweet and salty. Perfect mix. Would come again!
author: Calvin C.

description: Wow! I don't think I've had pastries this good in a very long time. A friend catered some of their offerings and they were all amazing. The croissants are flaky and crispy on the outside, soft on the inside. They also have different fillings...the chocolate chip cookies, morning buns, yum! Paired with your favorite coffee makes a perfect morning in my household. Too bad I don't live in the City, but I guess I could wake up earlier on occasion!
author: Gary N.

description: Everything from the place is very good and high quality. The line can be pretty long in the mornings but if you go after 11 you probably will find no one in line which is when I'll go pick up baked goods for work. It's pretty expensive for baked goods. I spent $15 on just 4 things, one of them being a standard cookie. It's a great place for a treat in the area though which is why I continue to go.
author: Kalani R.

description:
Delicious fresh pastries baked daily!  There is only outdoor seating available so dress warmly (or in layers) because you never know what San Francisco's weather will bring.  You can see all of the daily pastries (as some of the specialties rotate) on trays and order from them.

My favorite is the Ginger Pull-Apart...a giant conglomeration of layered flaky pastry knobs with crunchy caramelized ginger sugar on top. Just yum. No idea how they make this one but it's pretty awesome. The Pistachio Blackberry Twice-Baked is pretty amazing and last time I visited they also had a Hazelnut Raspberry Twice-Baked which was a decadent croissant topped with raspberry goodness and filled with a hazelnut spread inside. They also have some interesting savory combinations (e.g. Smoked Fish Cream Cheese Croissant).
author: Jess Y.

description:
Got here a little before 11 and was able to try the passionfruit mango doughnut bun and the guava cream cheese pastelito. The passionfruit mango doughnut bun was so magical! The filling was the right balance of tarty and sweet. Delicious! The guava cream cheese pastelito was interesting. It was very flaky and buttery. The flavor reminded me of the same guava cream cheese roll from Porto's bakery. Also very good. 

But the passionfruit mango doughnut bun! It's a must try!
author: Annie H.

description: They have many creative types of croissants. All taste very good. I tried their savory lunch item and it's also very good.
author: Melody H.

description:
Friendly staff! Great pastries! 
Tried their ham & cheese croissant and their ginger snap, the everything, and guava cheese croissant- still LOTS more to try. 
The sweet pastries are a bit too luxurious for me.. The ginger pull apart had great candied ginger, but a little too sugary for me. 
Guava roll was a bit buttery for me as well..
The ham & cheese is delicious! Flaky, savory meat & cheese filling. A perfect breakfast snack. 
I like the open concept of their kitchen... Once you walk in, you're basically in the kitchen. Outdoors bench for you sit and enjoy the muni as it passes by..
author: Maria C.

description:
Duuuude... I bought a whole buncha items one day midweek but the superstar was this passion fruit dough bun (passion fruit creme filled). Almond croissants were bomb. Cherry hazelnut twice baked was pretty tasty. They also have savory items like kimchi toast, croque madame and ham & cheese buns. 

There's usually a line out the door (fairly small) because the rest of the inside of the shop is the entire bakery. So, go and get some sweet hot buns, hun! 

*Picnic style tables out front for you to enjoy them pastries. Closes @ 2p for you late risers.
author: Jillian V.

description:
This small bakery is producing some creative and tasty pastries.

I had to get the Ginger Pull-apart and realy glad I did. Buttery, flaky, lovely candied ginger flavor and not overpowering. The guy in front of my got the last two Guava Cream Cheese Pastelito so I'll have to come back to try it. The Passionfruit Doughp sounded interesting, but it was a tad on the dry side but the passionfruit flavor was good.

Excited for my next trip back to try some other yummy pastries!
author: Lindsey C.

description:
Ah-mazing!!! Feeling so lucky a friend told me about this place. We stopped by around noon on a weekday and luckily found a parking spot about a block away.  There wasn't a line, which shocked me, especially after trying the food! A handful of items were sold out so I'll be back to try them! 

The pastries here are on par with the best (e.g. B Patisserie). I truly loved everything we got. We tried: 
-Kimchee bread
-Ham and cheese morning bun
-Chocolate claw
-Pistachio blackberry twice-baked
-Ginger pull-apart
-Sauerkraut smoked cheddar peppadew 
-Chocolate pudding dough bread

Service: SO FRIENDLY. I so love it when there's a smile to greet you and people are willing to answer questions. Given how yummy the food was, they could easily have an uppity attitude, but that totally wasn't the case. 

Ambiance: Cute place with some outdoor seating. Luckily since they don't need refrigeration or heat (they recommended a toaster oven but were delicious without) you can take them anywhere!
author: Susan G.

description:
These Guys! I gave thumbs up to firefighters scrambling in for their morning jolt suggesting the hazelnut cherry croissant because Yes that's the way to roll. Always friendly and Extra Excellent on Everything they Bake! 

Special mentions:
Bagels delicious crunch fresh baked
Ginger pull thingy makes the eyes roll sideways 
Macchiato is De La Paz smooth operator

5 stars and ten hearts!! 

Recently brought loaves of their polenta bread to a BBQ and it was the BIG hit of the meal. Large sized loaves with crusty edges r perfect when skatgerd on one side w your fave spread now Thas wat I call summertime thank you guys you rule the SF bake scene
author: Lisa S.

description:
My co-worker has brought goodies in from this place a few times, everything looks SO good. I have only had the chocolate drop, and oh my goodness, if you like chocolate this is for you, even if you're not a chocolate fan, I think you'll like this. So light and airy and the chocolate is not too sweet.

It is near my workplace, but I'm scared to step foot in there as I'd want everything.
author: Kathryn Y.

description:
I loved the feel of this bakery. They don't lay their pastries out in a pretty glass case, but have it laying on the metal trays behind the cashier. It was pretty hard to choose from all the options.  

We tried the passion fruit bun and the guava and cheese strudel. We grabbed a seat outside, on a long bench and enjoyed our pastries. The passion fruit bun had lots of tart filing inside that was really good. If you don't want something sweet, this is for you. The guava and cheese strudel reminded me of Portos in LA. Very similar in taste but less filling, but I like Portos better. Overall, a cute bakery and I'll be back to try their other items.
author: Vy T.

description:
Please Yelp, build an option for 6 stars. My brother told me about this bakery and we took a morning run (gotta earn it) to see if it lived up to the hype that he heard about. I don't even have much of a sweet tooth, but this was everything and more.

We ordered the following 3:
Ham and Cheese Morning Bun (4/5): Oh man, the texture and color were gorgeous. You could see the individual layers of the bun which resembled a croissant in bun-form and the outer shell had a great flake to it. We were a little disappointed to find that the center was largely hollow but quickly got over it when we tasted it. The inside was moist without being too dense and the cheese was incorporated beautifully with the dough. The slice of ham provided a nice contrast in texture while adding to the savoriness of the bun.

Passionfruit pastry (4.5/5): When we cut this piece in half, the dough looked airy and almost dry and we expected it to be a bit on the dry side just based on looks. Boy were we proven wrong. The dough had was anything but dry but still had a good amount of bite and fluffiness to it. The passionfruit creme on the inside was generous and just the right amount of tart to counter the sweetness of the powdered sugar on the exterior.

Pistachio Blackberry Twice Baked (5/5): This. This piece is a slice of heaven. I love both pistachios and blackberries but never thought of trying the combination until now and it was absolutely gorgeous. The filling was amazingly soft and moist; the slight saltiness and nuttiness of the pistachio balanced out the sweetness of the blackberries perfectly and resulted in a bite that was just the right amount of sweetness. I'll get this one every time I come back.

I'm glad we swung by this spot. One thing to note is that they close early and apparently close when they run out for the day so the earlier you swing by, the better!
author: Jason W.

description:
Came for brunch, we grabbed 4 pastries (2 savory, 2 sweet) and 2 coffees ended up being only $22! Not bad for SF brunch, considering a meal for one consisting of mediocre eggs could be the same. On the pastry quality alone it's between a 4 and 5 but rounding up. I don't like overly sweet desserts so, the pastries are the perfect level of slight sugariness, layers of flour and butter - clearly fresh and made with high quality ingredients.

Was it among the best pastries I've had? No, not mindblowingly good, but still pretty damn good. I'd say top tier for SF and very reasonable for the price. Neighbor Bakehouse is way better than Tartine, but the craftsmanship level is not as high as b. patisserie, nor are the pastries as delicate. The best part is it's not crowded, but that'll probably change. Outdoor seating, bus your own tables, lemon and lime water at the station.

We sampled a few of these
Orange Hazelnut Financier (3/5) - Soft crumb cake like and fairly uniform texture throughout. Interesting flavor, with bits of candied orange.
Ginger Pull Apart Bread (4/5) - Subtle cinnamon sugar and ginger, some pieces are drier and flaky, some pieces are layers of softer, buttery dough, but one of my favorite parts is how the bottom gets slightly chewy and hardened caramelized crust piece.
Ham and Cheese Morning Bun (3.5/5) - The cheese congealed into a big chunk around the center, sliced ham also lay in a swirl in between the outer part and inner. Sunflower and poppy seeds line the outside.
Kimchi Sauerkraut Tart (4/5) - Bread was buttery and amazing, kimchi could be spicier, cheese wasn't really necessary. I found that much more filling than the morning bun.

I've also had the
Twice Baked Pistachio Blueberry Croissant (4.5/5) - Really good and where the technique shows. The almond paste is filled inside and caked on the outside forming a gooey layer on top of a flaky croissant. A little one the dry side due to the twice-baked ness. Dusted with powdered sugar.
author: Truc N.

description:
Important to note, this place closes at 2, so plan accordingly. 

This place offers a lot of interesting takes on croissants in addition to their plain croissant. I feel like...I might be unfair to this place as I am pretty traditional when it comes to croissants...I just like them plain most of the time...and you can sway me with the occasional almond or ham and cheese...but overall I prefer traditional plain croissants. Now that we got that out of the way...I wasn't a huge fan of the takes because I think they were out of my croissant comfort zone. 

Pistachio blackberry twice-baked croissant - It was a little too sweet and by double baking it...lots of the flakiness that I love about a croissant goes away. 
Everything croissant - I was intrigued...because everything bagels and the everything but the bagel seasoning from trader joes are two of my favorite things. So I went all in and was mildly disappointed...there was cream cheese in the croissant...like a bagel. I dunno...I guess I wasn't expecting it and didn't really care for it. 
Plain Croissant - they ran out when we first got in, but right before we left, a fresh batch just came out! It was good, but a little too much butter and not enough flaky. It was delicious...but I think it was partially because it was still hot (there is nothing better than hot, fresh bread...even if its gross bread but fresh from the oven) so I feel like it got an unfair advantage because it was still warm. As I was biting into it, I felt that I was eating a warm, fresh from the oven, costco croissant, and I mean no disrespect - costco croissants when fresh are good. 

I probably would not make the drive out again, but I'm glad I tried.
author: Kathy L.

description:
As far as bakeries go in San Francisco, this is one of the most innovative and reliable. Any bakery that opens at 6:30am is one well-oiled operation, as the employees must start working sometime around 5am.

The selection of pastries and breads is incredibly diverse. My favorites were the ginger pull-apart bread and blackberry pistachio croissant. I thought the everything croissant and ham and cheese croissant were just okay, so I'd recommend the sweet over the savory.

Also a coffee bar with plenty of different drinks, although I'm not a big coffee person. Came here on a weekday morning and waited about 15 minutes in line, must be much longer on the weekends.
author: Tim X.

description:
Okay, the hype about Neighbor Bakehouse is real!  I bought a chocolate claw and a ham & cheese morning bun (total $8).  By the time we arrived on Saturday after 12, there were a handful of items sold out that I wanted to try.  

The chocolate claw was pretty much a twisted chocolate croissant.   It was filled with decadent chocolate and so flaky and buttery!  I left the morning bun for the morning and gently toasted it in my toaster oven.  It had a light filling of ham and cheese with a dusting of poppy seeds on the bottom.  It was a good savory treat for breakfast.  

There's plenty of outdoor seating via tables and benches, and some savory sandwiches.  There were about two staff members helping out customers.  Neighbor Bakehouse does offer some delicious gourmet pastries, but I prefer the refinement and delicate artworks from B Patisserie.
author: Cat C.

description:
Well I cannot give enough of 5 stars reviews. I just simply love this place

Tips: I think they start to have most of their item starting around 7am or little bit after that. They run low starting 12;30pm, I assume that they start to prepare the last batch around that time. i used to come before 7, they did not have a lot of stuff, and I came around 1:00pm and they run out most of their stuff. Well, I came frequent enough so if you are around the area, I think 7-830pm would be a good time where you don't need to wait for too long.
author: Stephanie H.

description:
I love everything about Neighbor Bakehouse - the location, the outdoor seating, and - of course - the food.

We usually order their amazing "everything" croissants at Four Barrel so we thought - why not check out the source!

We went by for breakfast on a Sunday morning.  There was a line - but it moves quickly.  People basically point to the pastries they want, pay, grab, and go.  When it was our turn, we ordered the smoked salmon croissant, the sauerkraut cheddar tart, a muffaletta, the croque madame, and the chocolate pudding dough bun.  Way more than two people needed, but my eyes are bigger than my stomach - by a lot!

I loved everything.  I still think the "everything" croissant is my favorite item, but everything we tried on this particular day was awesome.  I personally think it's better than Tartine / Tartine Manufactory.

We also had a coffee and an almond latte which were better-than-average.

As I mentioned, the outdoor seating is nice and spacious.  Despite the volume of people ordering and eating, there was always enough room at the picnic tables - and people tend to eat and leave pretty quickly.

The only challenge coming here is parking.  They don't have their own parking, as they use their spots for the picnic tables.  If you come early enough, street parking is possible, though it gets harder as the morning goes on.
author: Tay H.

description:
Wow this place is so far my favorite bakery in San Francisco!! Can they teach me how to bake like that???
I still have yet to try Mr. Holmes (not down for the early wait in line), but so far this place is hard to beat!
I first had their Everything Crossiant at another cafe and it blew me away. I had to come to the OG location, so I drove to this place at 10am on a Saturday. There was a line out the door, but it went by quickly with 10 people ahead of me. I hate waiting in line in the cold, but the croissants were calling me and I couldn't say no.
I got a box of 6 pastries and in my box I had:

EVERYTHING CROISSANT (5/5)
Hands.down.best.sh*t.ever.just.get.it.dont.question.me.
This croissant was flak y and crunchy (from the poppy seeds), yet soft and fluffy on the inside. Love love love the cream cheese filling inside. Sounds so simple yet it blew my mind everytime I take a bite. My sister was sneaking bites and practically devoured 1/3 of it when I wasn't looking. It's that seriously that good.

SAUERKRAUT TART (4.5/5)
This was recommended by one of the worker and it's one of of my top favorite now too. It's crunchy and buttery. I love pastries with multi flavors and this hits the spot with sourness from the filling and the savorness from the baked cheese. Reminds me of those savory bread from a Chinese bakery, but with an updated bread base.

PISTACHIO BLACKBERRY TWICE BAKED (4.5/5)
This is my sister's all time favorite (still like the everything croissant better). I didn't know pistachio can be incorporated like this in a croissant! The pistachio was creamy and it mixed so well with the flaky soft texture of the croissant. Sadly my sister devoured it before I get a piece of it with the blackberry.

HAM AND CHEESE MORNING BUN (3/5)
Honestly I got this one because it was pretty. Maybe because I ate it hours after I got it so it wasn't super fresh, but it was medicore. Don't get me wrong it was good, but compared to the other amazing pastries they had it just didn't stand out.

PASSION FRUIT DOUGHP BUN (4/5)
Yum yum yum. The passion fruit filling was refreshing after eating all of the savory carbs. It wasn't too overwhelming like I expected and compliments the breading around the cream.

GERMAN COFFEE CAKE (4/5)
Another refreshing treat after eating the savory pastries. Don't remember exactly the taste of it, but it wasn't disappointing either.

Overall everything was bomb.com and everyone needs to come here. The end.
author: Grace Z.

description:
As soon as I saw SF CM Ben's picture of the passion fruit croissant from Neighbor, bookmark!!  Since I wanted to hit up his other reco Plow for breakfast/brunch, I knew I needed to be committed and get myself up NLT 6:30AM on a Sunday so I can get the best of both worlds while minimizing my wait time.  We arrived at Neighbor around 7:30 when most of SF is still sleeping and therefore super quiet as we walked up which immediately reminded me of my early morning arrival in Portland Maine not too long ago before it started bustling.  Just like Two Fat Cats in Portland, most of their freshly baked pastries are still on racks upon walking in enticing me to get more than I really needed.  

Passion Fruit DoughP Bun - This was my favorite one that I wished my husband didn't forget the cooler so I could take one to go since the cream of the DoughP requires refrigeration if you don't eat it soon after purchase.  

2 Pistachio Blackberry Twice Baked Croissant - My second favorite as it was not overly sweet and I love the nuttiness of the whole pistachios giving it a good balance.  

Two Morning Buns with Ham and Gruyere - It was good but I kind of wish there was a little more gruyere in it to fill in the hole in the middle.  

Hazelnut Candy Orange Financier - This was on the dense side kind of like a pound cake

Ginger Pull Apart - Upon first bite, I wasn't a fan but as I continued, I liked it more.  Good for sharing but probably a bit too much for one person especially if you want to try other pastries.  

Overall, Neighbor Bakehouse is a great friendly neighborhood bakery that I just wish was in my neighborhood but then again, it is probably better for our waistline that it is a 45+ min drive away, making it more of a treat than an addiction!!
author: Joyce Z.

description:
I was in the city for work and stopped by Neighbor Bakehouse since it was super close by. When you enter the store, you basically walk into a large kitchen and order your items. It was a rainy day, so I wanted to eat there but they only have outdoor tables. 

Ham & gruyere morning bun- Good ratio of dough to ham and cheese. Good but not as great as the ham & cheese brioche at Manresa!

Croissant- Husband didn't think it was anything special (he prefers a more buttery croissant)

Twice-baked blackberry & pistachio croissant- This one was good. The combination of blackberry and pistachio was unique, and the two ingredients complemented each other very well. I'd get this one again!

Passion fruit doughp bun- The passion fruit filling was delicious: tart and not overly sweet, it went perfectly with the brioche.

Sourdough country loaf- Nice chewy dough inside and great sourdough flavor. Good value for $6!

Additional notes: Breads, croissants, brioche, tarts, toasts, and macaroons. Items were ~$3-4/each, except for the larger items. Order a bunch to go and enjoy them at home or the park. Friendly service and a bakery that I'd return to! I'm curious about their sandwiches and kim chi toast..
author: Patti F.

description:
I arrive just before closing so most things were sold out. Staff was incredibly friendly and what I did get was great!
Need to go back earlier to try out more of their menu.
author: Liz N.

description: I've come here a few times on weekend mornings and am happy to report that the line has usually been no more than 10min long, even on a Sun at 11am. My favorites are the chocolate croissant, mushroom croissant, and kimchi toast. The latter looks like someone barfed up last night's party onto their toast.. but don't be deterred, it tastes awesome!
author: Jean L.

description: This place is always awesome. It's hands down the best bakery in SF. Great pastries, bread and sandwiches in the afternoon. We come here all the time.
author: Matt K.

description: Bakery name may be unassuming, but everything else is outstanding. Ginger pull apart was perfect in textures with right balance of ginger. The pistachio blackberry croissant was also an explosion of flavors. The raspberry macaroon was also perfect level of sweetness that brought out the coconut. There is one parking spot in front which has been open on all of my visits so far and outdoor patio is pet friendly.
author: Sumit S.

description: Have you ever wonder why all the coffee shops make the same delicious pistachio croissants? It's because they all got it from Neighbor Bakehouse! Thank you for making getting up early worthwhile!
author: Yuhuan T.

description: Coffee was great, thought for a bakery the pastry could have tasted a little fresher. Had the pistachio and blackberry croissant which I have had numerous times and is always a hit. Their other pastries such as a German crumb cake was lacking in flavor. Fototica/pizza was great just wish they could heat it. Hit or miss with the pastries.
author: Brandon F.

description:
The quality and innovation of the baked goods at Neighbor Bakehouse is jaw dropping. 
It kind of shocks you.  The place is sunny and unpretentious, the staff is kind and unassuming.
And the baked goods are brain shifting in their unexpected twists, surprises and subtlety.  
When you think you've had the ultimate croissant---theirs will give you more information on how a croissant can be.  The passion fruit coconut tart is a sin.  Way too good.  Anyone who loves good sweet and savory baked goods you have to go here.
author: Portia S.

description:
Perhaps Totoro would be sad that Neighbor now has a closer connotation with a bakery than the OG, My Neighbor Totoro. Anyways, I digress.

While the juggernauts Tartine and B. patesserie remain packed, there is increasing popularity for pop-up-type bakeries. Indeed, Neighbor's homemade style features unique creations such as the ginger pull-apart and everything croissant. The baking skillz are superb, with pastry layers crisped to flakey perfection and a crunchy, caramelized exterior very similar to Arsicault. 

I got some type of croissant and something custardy--the exact name/descriptions are beside the point, as the pastries were phenomenal without the need for cognitive bias surrounding the excitement of eating a "pistachio blackberry twice-baked croissant". Although it's a tad bit too sweet, overall the flavors and textures are on point. Bonus points for the cute packaging with twine around the paper box.

The itself place is very small business-like, cozy and not particularly gentrified (though one could beg to differ for any foodie-oriented bakery that turns basic baked goodies into bouge luxuries, with very-above-average price tags).
author: Edna C.

description: I'm a bakery owner and was visiting from Arizona . I went to several bakeries today. And this one. By far is my favorite! I loved loved all the pastries we tried they were absolutely amazing!!
author: Victoria T.

description:
Great place, stopped today to get some food and hot drinks for the road it was delicious. The food is so fresh and taste so good plus The service there is really good 
Definitely coming back
author: Mai D.

description:
Finally here!! And actually got inside shortly before they close. Everything looked great and I wanted everything. I came after brunch therefore I was stuffed already but since I'm in the Dogpatch I had to get some neighbor bakehouse. I had their pastries before because many coffee shops sell them, a few in the fidi. Already knew how delicious their baked goods are. Selections at coffee shops are small. Only had their pistachio blueberry croissant and raspberry lime coconut macaroon. They were both so good, therefore i was super excited for the visit. Pastry heaven.

Everyone was super nice. BEST SERVICE compared to all the bakeries in the city! Staff was super sweet and friendly. 

I got 2 of **Smoked ham and gruyere morning bun. So good. Very flaky. The layers of croissant texture and the look of a morning bun. Its topped with sunflower and poppy seeds. Presentation look great and extremely delicious! 

**GINGER PULL APART - Have you had the b. patisserie's kouign amann? It's similar but I think this is better, much better. It's made with caramelized with grated ginger, cane sugar and brown sugar. OMGoodness. So crispy and flaky on the outside and soft and moist on the inside. It's not over powering sweet. And the pull apart is huge and it pulls away easily. ha! Can be breakfast for two days or for your lunch. Amazingly delicious! 

Can't wait to come back and try everything else!
author: Sandy B.

description: You know this place is awesome when they 1) don't take online ordering & 2) they're closed Mondays & Tuesdays (because they deserve weekday breaks).  This is like one of my favorite bakeries in the city, but it's sooooo far away from my home.  I only came down here based on a recommendation.  And I never waste a trip because I order almost everything that I see and can fit in the box.  My all time favorite:  Croque madame...warm it up and it is a savory heaven!  I got their ginger pull apart and it does not taste anything you would have imagine....meaning I could barely taste the ginger which is a good thing. The kimchee toast has a unique flavor, but not too spicy for my taste buds.  The ham and cheese morning bun does live up to it's name and it tastes better than how 85 degree makes it.  I can't remember everything else I got, but they were all heavenly. I'm overdue for another visit!
author: Lisa W.

description:
The best bakery in San Francisco, hands down. You will have a religious experience with their twice baked croissants. Much more supple and not dry at all like many other double baked croissants here in sf. 

Everything croissant is ridiculous. 

Chocolate pudding bun is insane. 

Neighbor Bakehouse, I love you.
author: Alexandria W.

description:
Where do I start? I mean you have to try everything. The croissants are amazing. I'm not kidding. The bagels are great, and the ham and cheese morning bun. So good. I'm not joking. Sooooooo dang good. 
Everyone here is nice and helpful. They always have someone wiping off the tables so that everyone gets a clean table to sit at. It's also always so so busy. But worth the wait. I promise you. 
Overall, Neighbor Bakehouse is the place to go to start your day off right.  (Wednesday through Sundays)
author: Joey G.

description:
We are fans. What else can I say! We live outside the city, but make it a point to stop here every time we pass through San Francisco in the day time. Our favorites are the ginger pull apart (flaky, not too sweet, with a subtle ginger flavor), and my husband always gets the veggie tartine which is loaded with cheese and vegetables. He loves the latte there (I'm not a coffee drinker). We often get the mushroom tart and sauerkraut smoked cheddar peppadew tart which are both delicious. This last weekend I tried the guava and cream cheese pastelito for the first time. I don't know if it beats Porto's in southern California, but it is a lovely norcal alternative. We have passed on our recommendation to this place to lots of San Francisco visitors as we truly believe it is a gem. 

Note parking is not easy in this area and expect to circle around for a bit before you find a spot. Also the queue area and seating are both outside (inside is just the actual baking and cash counter), so be prepared for this if it's raining!
author: Richa B.

description:
I always pick up their ginger pull-apart bread every time I go after flip flopping between "do I want something else as well... no... i need self-control." I love the crunchy exterior with the ginger encrusted bottom. I love the sensation of pulling apart the "good stuff" that's on the outside - like picking apart the edges of a brownie. Only problem is that the inside is SUPER greasy. Meh not a fan after I pick out the the edges. The baguette is solid but nothing special.

It's kind of small space where there's not really a place to "line up" despite the popularity. However, if you see a line, do not despair! It moves very quickly! Cute space outside to munch on your goodies. There's definitely a wide selection of waist-expanding pastries. So bring your self-control with you or ... you know leave it at the door bc life is too short to carb count.
author: Cindy W.

description: This is my new favorite bakery everything is scrumptious. The chocolate pudding morning bun is so delicious sweet with a little salty. I was surprised how much I love the ginger pull apart
author: Patricia R.

description:
This place reminds me of Mr.Holmes Bakehouse minus the Cruffin. But they're special in their own way and just as delicious. 

We got here around 8am on a Saturday and no line, but a good amount of people sitting outside (even in the cold) already with their bake goods - great sign.

THE GOODS:
We got 5 baked goods: 
1) Ginger Pull-apart - fresh out of the oven and totally lives up to the hype! Each bite was so crisp and flaky. The ginger is pretty subtle near the top, but definitely taste it closer to the bottom. I also love how it's not too sweet
2) Pistachio and blackberry twice baked - bites of flaky and gooey goodness inside (in a good way!) Pistachio was subtly and not too much blackberries which I liked.
3) Ham and Cheese - a little too butter and salty for me, but flaky-ness on point. 
4) Guava & Cheese - tbt
5) Chocolate Croissant - tbt

Pricing a little on the higher side, but I guess it's the norm for bakeries like these. 

SERVICE:
The guy that helped us was very patient and helpful, gave us some good recommendations too! 

AMBIANCE:
All seating is outdoor and picnic bench/cafeteria style. The who ordering set up inside can be improved. The ordering counter is a little crowded/small. They should have more menus/bigger meun posted so more people can look at them before making their order. But you can see all the baking happening inside which is pretty cool. They also have all the bake goods labeled behind the counter so you can see how each one looks like. Again, their set up for this can also be improved. 

Will I be back? Yes! But only in the area, because it is a 20min drive for me to get here.
author: Samantha F.

description:
The absolute Best BAKERY in San Francisco .

Service is stellar!  Always a line, but it moves quick!  

Pastries are like heaven.  They always use the freshest ingredients and it's consistent every time
author: Heather H.

description:
Yum!  Solid 4.5 stars.  Everything we had here was pretty good.  In terms of visual appeal, most of their pastries are relatively dark in color (so they look dry and not sweet), but don't let looks deceive you.  This was good for me so I didn't order everything--some other bakeries make me want everything, but this one visually limited my lust.  Neighbor's flaky buttery pastries rival b. Patisserie's (but nothing comes close to b's Kouign Amann), though their menus differ completely with the exception of the plain croissant.

Cinnamon Almond Bostock ($4) - basically a buttery slice of cinnamon bread slathered with almond frangipane.  Really good with flaky ends and melt-in-your-mouth soft buttery center.  Almond frangipane is sweet but no too sweet, with a relatively generous portion of soft sweet almonds.  Think of this as a less greasy, slightly more firm almond croissant.

Pistachio Blackberry Twice-Baked ($4) - basically a sliced croissant with blackberry jam and pistachio creamy crumble inside.  The pistachio innards are fantastic, and the croissant is flaky outside, buttery, and moist inside.

Ham and Cheese Morning Bun ($4.25) - interior is rolled in sesame seeds and poppy seeds which really distinguishes this from your typical ham and cheese pastry.  Really soft and tasty, but cheese formed a hard disc on the bottom which I didn't particularly care for, however this is a good savory option.

Ginger Pull-Apart Bread ($3.75) - hubby liked it.  I liked the buttery pieces (personally not a fan of ginger), however the pastry was not consistent throughout--some pieces super buttery, some super gingery, some slightly dry.  Hubby would get again, but I'd pass, as if prefer for it to be more consistent and moist throughout.  Overhyped in my opinion.

Chocolate Pudding Dough Bread ($4) - good pudding interior and nice salty crunchy chocolatey bits on top.  However, the bread itself was slightly dry--I understand how another Yelper mentioned it tasted stale...I don't think it's really stale (they're constantly turning pastries with the constant line at this place!)--I think it's just that the bread has to be relatively harder to hold its shape with the liquidy pudding inside.  I warmed it up in the microwave for 12 seconds--but that was probably 10 seconds too long, because the pudding became chocolate milk.  Tasty but messy pudding!  I would only get again if I were craving chocolate and happened to be here--otherwise id prefer a b. Patisserie nutella Kouign Amann or even a La Boulangerie chocolate pot de creme danish.

Eat outside at the multiple picnic benches or take out.  Free parking on side streets and Illinois.  They accept credit cards via iPad Square (not sure why another Yelper said cash only).
author: Vanessa O.

description:
I'd like to jump on the train and agree with all the five-star reviews for Neighbor. I have literally nothing to add, except that it was freakin' delicious, totally worth the cost, and the lines go faster than any other overhyped bakery - which I attribute to the fact that the inside isn't completely photogenic, so you're literally craning your neck to see the pastry carts, placing your order, and paying. Nothing worthy of your Instagram. Yay for quick lines.

We ordered four pastries (after I already ate half of an avocado toast earlier at Provender...) around 11 AM on Saturday. A good 10-15 people in line with all the tables pretty full. You could tell that this place attracts both locals and tourists.

Plain croissant 5/5 - the best that the boyfriend has ever had and he would eat croissants every day if he could...and he used to do just that...

Everything croissant 4/5 - good, but too much going on

Pistachio & Blackberry croissant - 5/5 my personal favorite, nothing overwhelming and a great combo

Ham & Cheese bun 3.5/5 - nothing too impressive, needs more cheese!

Total for four was $14! Super satisfying. We're obviously croissant lovers and Neighbor Bakehouse lovers...
author: Lucy Z.

description:
Whoa. I was exploring the Dogpatch neighborhood last Saturday and stumbled into this little gem on a whim. Needless to say, I didn't expect this stop to be so memorable. 

To my knowledge, they bake all of their goods at this location and the three that I purchased were amazing! 

Ham, Poppyseed, Mustard Pastry - OH MY DEAR MAMA. This is what you order when you go there. Seriously, just go and get one for lunch. 
Passion Fruit Croissant - the layer of passion fruit custard was stupid. 
Blackberry & Pistachio Croissant - Not overly sweet, just amazing. 

They also had cold brew that must have been powered by in a nitrous oxide (the same set up as Guinness) becuase it came out with the consistency of the beer I just mentioned. Holy moly. I've never experinced cold brew like that before and it was better than any I've had in the city. No joke.

Do yourself a favor and head here after work because the rest of the day is sure to be a let down :)
author: Benjamin F.

description: The line is often quite long when we go but moves pretty fast and parking is not too difficult, just circle the block once or twice.  We usually stop by on weekends and get the passion fruit dough bun and guava and cheese pastalito.  Flavored are strong but not in your face sweet.  They do have savory options too such as pizza at this bakery.  The prices are standard for a trendy bakery so nothing too out of the ordinary.
author: Alexander C.

description:
4.5 stars

Is it worth the hype?  I would have to say that yes, it is.  I had been able to visit Arsicault the week prior to allow for a comparison as well.  It's a tough life in SF!  

I ordered a sample of items to share and try.  They were out of plain croissants (WHAT!) so I ordered an Everything Croissant, the ham and cheese morning bun, the guava and cream cheese pastelito and small country loaf.  

The Everything Croissant was good but was my least favorite of the items purchased that day.  I'm just not a fan of cream cheese in my croissant.  Perhaps this was due to me not expecting it to be there.  The croissant itself was light and airy on the outside with a bit of chew on the inside.  

The savory morning bun was delicious.  For me it beats the the Rebel Within at Craftsman & Wolves.  Perhaps that is not a good comparison as they are not exactly alike (pastry vs. muffin) but in terms of a savory breakfast treat, this morning bun is it.  I even prefer this over the ham and cheese croissant at Arsicault.

The guava and cream cheese pastelito was good but I wish there had been a bit more of the guava.  The pastry itself was really good but we were looking for a higher ratio of filling to dough.

The country loaf was really good.  The crust was not to thick and had a bit of chew.  The interior was dense, moist, tender and hole-y.  I didn't find the loaf that sour at all.  We tried the bread with butter, cheese, pate and even avocado.  It was a great base when paired with other items or fine on its own. 

My visit was on a Friday at 9:30 am.  On this day, parking looked to be a difficult as others have mentioned.  For the normally quiet period during the holiday week, I was hoping this area would be fairly deserted.  No chance.  I was luckily enough to find a spot at the end of the block, around the corner, without much difficulty.  On a weekday I would recommend coming with someone that can drop you off or look for parking while you hop out to pick up the pastries.  The lined moved fairly quickly and I don't think I waited more than 5 minutes, which allowed me ample time to peruse the menu and look to see what was available on the racks.  There is no place to sit inside as the space is allocated to the baking operations.  There are a few tables outside.

I hear parking is much easier on the weekends but the lines are much longer.  Hopefully it won't take me another year to make a return trip!
author: Melissa L.

description: Must get in here and eat EVERYTHING! I happened to catch  them on a local food show and saw the almond powdered sugar toast thing they make. Holy god! Life changing. Stop reading and go eat! Now!
author: Christian L.

description:
Best bakery I've yet to visit - we stayed at our friend's place this last weekend and were delighted to see that this bakery was just a couple blocks away ! We treated ourselves to a spread of yummies: 

Pistachio blackberry twice-baked croissant - SUPER flaky and caramelized on the outside
Ginger pullapart - Typically ginger is very overpowering but it was subtle enough to be very enjoyable
Cinnamon almond bostock - My favorite of the bunch, my favorite flavors in a hefty bite
Chocolate pudding doughnut bun - Underwhelming but the amount of pudding does not disappoint!
Passionfruit fruit coconut macaron - tropical colorful flavors together, delish !
Passionfruit doughnut bun - my husband's favorite, the passionfruit was so strong !
Smoked trout and cream cheese croissant - Yummmmmm 
Guava and cream cheese pastelito - Guava was not as strong as I hoped it'd be but still delish !
author: Crystal N.

description:
Bossman: "You know, my intermittent fasting isn't working because of you guys" 

Me: "True, but you only eat morning buns from Neighbor Bakehouse intermittently (ha). Plus it's so flaky and airy, so you basically save 50% calories versus a croissant." 

Bossman: "You're so smart. I'll put you in for a promotion ..."

Kidding. That's not how it went down. 

There might not be any promotion in sight, but my future work days have become more promising since I have a co worker who lives near Neighbor Bakehouse. Thanks to her, we've sampled their blackberry croissant, smoked ham and gruyere morning bun, ginger pull aparts and chocolate croissant. Everything is so fresh, made with high quality ingredients (thank you BUTTER!) and just bursting with flavor. 

OH. MY. GAH. 

I thought the holiday gluttony was over, I detoxed for like 2 days and here we are back again at square one. 

FML.
author: Janice C.

description:
The best pastries in San Francisco hands down! I own the business next door and I cannot tell you how many customers come in absolute ecstasy about the delicious pastry and coffee they just had next door! In addition to pastries, Muffuletta sandwiches, and bagels they also have the BEST chocolate chip cookie I've ever had! Seriously! It all is a must try if you are in San Francisco and want to hang out in the hottest neighborhood - Dogpatch! 
Plus--- a really cool thing is Greg and his wife are the nicest and hardest working people I know and the staff is exuberant about working there. What more could you ask for!
author: Bonnie G.

description: Worth writing about! Worth making to extra effort to get here! The dough was light and buttery - and the savories were filled with quality cheese and meat slices. The ham and cheese bun was flakey, perfectly cheesy, and the ham was pure deliciousness! The chocolate chip cookie was amazingly chocolatey- light and a little crunchy- not too gooey. The Madame slice of sourdough had a layer of pizza sauce, one egg, cheese, caramelized  onions and the ham soaked the protein palate!
author: Jeanette S.

description:
Muffins, Turnovers, Tarts and Buns on sale make it sound like they are your usual bakery. Every visit here guarantees a lavish affair to treat your taste buds. Cappuccinos with oat milk or a cold brew are my weekend indulgence coffee options.

Try out the Muffuletta sandwich, Curried Potato Turnover and the Praline Doughp Bun.
On your second visit get the Butter Croissant, Mushroom Tart and Blueberry Muffin.
author: Samridh C.

description:
I phantom smell the everything croissant. The poppyseed, garlic, cream cheese combo sounded unintuitive to me, but was like I'd died and gone to heaven when it made it into my mouth!

I also loved the bostock, which is a vanilla-y, eggy croissant. Lighter than French toast and denser than croissant. Super yum!

Came on a rainy weekend = abundant parking and no lines. Yay!!!
author: Kathryn C.

description:
After reading all these 5 stars review, it was a mission to try this place.  I have had failed numerous attempts not being able to find parking and/or frightened by the wait of massive people already lined up wrapping around the building; note to myself avoid coming on weekends! 

.....so I came last Friday around noon and to my delight, I was the second person with no one behind me. I had ordered only 3 items cuz the 'RUDE-MOFU' employee abruptly told me my second items were by the paying counter.  I had to abruptly tell that mofu to add one more item and he did then ignored me without asking 'would you like to order more' or 'anything else to add' or 'are your order complete?' like many reputable establishment with SUPERB customer service; common f'effin sense!  I may be petite, but I can eat, so what's the f'effin rush when you had no sign that said limit 1-3 purchases and no one behind me!!!!!! I get it, IF I was one of those bad customer that took more than 5-10 indecisive minutes, but I didn't, so no reason to be f'effin rude/BAD customer service!

Ginger-pull apart - not had, could barely taste any ginger, and quite addictive; explains why this was their number 1 seller; 1 star

Chocolate Pudding Doughy - Extremely disappointing, Yelpers!!!!!  The whole dome except for the bottom crust was not flaky and DRY. The chocolate pudding/filling inside was mediocre.  I ate most of the chocolate & the tasty, slight chewy, sweet crunchy bottom crust while the rest was fed to the pigeons! Zero star

Raspberry Violet Hazelnut Twice-baked Croissant - not bad, and Arsicault's croissants better; 1 star

Sorry to be the first to publish my honest  stars....NO plans to return any time soon to try their other pastries thanks to that RUDE-MOFU Asian employee with wannabe blonde streaks/dye!
author: Katy N.

description:
I wish I lived right next to this place! I would go everyday to eat all their amazing pastries!! My friend suggested this place on my recent trip to SF. You know it has got to be great when there's a long line out the door and you see everyone walking away with boxes of the stuff! 

The croissants are a must order! Try all of them! The Everything Croissant was amazing! The everything topping on top was flavorful and the stuffed cream cheese inside the croissant was like a party in your mouth! The layers of croissant were light and fluffy, the outside had a slight crisp. We ate that one right then and there, and wished we had ordered another one. 

I ended up taking a huge box of pastries home to share with my family in LA. Even though it was the next day, everything still tasted great! The Ham and Cheese morning bun was delicious with ooey cheese after warming it up in the toaster oven. The twice baked croissant with pistachios and blackberries was delicious as well! The doughpy bun is a donut with filling. I got the passionfruit one which I found a bit on the tart side, but the bun itself was really tasty! I also bought the ginger pastry, guava roll, and some other items that I didn't actually get to taste for myself. 

Definitely a must go the next time in SF. I feel a bit bad for cheating on Tartine, but this place is really really good! My only complaint is that they don't have a large paper bag if you order the big box. I ended up having to carry the box with both hands all the way to the airport and onto the plane!
author: Vickie C.

description:
I came here with my friend as a break from the Nano Tech Fair in Dogpatch and she told me about this bakery! Alas, there was a line, but not be deterred as we only waited 10 minutes! 

FOOD: Ham and Cheese Morning Bun. I am used to sweet MBs but this one was a nice twist on the classic MB. With the ham and cheese incorporated into the bun itself, the bun provided a nice flakey texture with a soft chew of the ham, surrounded with the saltiness of the cheese. For $4.50, it's not the cheapest pastry, but it is San Francisco and I'm sure the food is locally sourced and organic. 

SERVICE: Speedy. Friendly. Nothing wrong with it at all! I love when a bakery is effective.

Overall, one of the better bakeries in San Francisco compared to some of the better known ones that are geared towards tourists. I'd recommend it if you are in the area even though Dogpatch is hard to reach, you'll be rewarded!
author: Albert H.

description: What is worth a 30 minute wait on Saturday mornings? This place. Quality pastries, excellent coffee, and exceptional staff. Local tip: get here before 8am to avoid the line. My fave is the pistachio raspberry twice baked!
author: Sarah H.

description: Met my sister here for brunch on a visit to SF and tried a couple of pastries which ranged from good to amazing. Kind of regret not trying the everything croissant but we went for a savory tart (good) and a twice-baked croissant (amazing!). It was a weekday morning, no lined but really hard time finding parking.
author: Katerina T.

description:
If you like savory pastries come here, now, or when they're open, which can be a little limiting, so check hours of operation first.

They also have sweet pastries. My daughter ordered a chocolate croissant. I had a bite. And yes, I slowly enunciated, "Yummm," while raising my eyebrows and smiling.

And, in case you were wondering, they have excellent coffee. (Sometimes these little bakeries have the bomb baked goods and then (sad trombone) ghetto coffee.) but you'll get good coffee here. Don't worry.

It's a production line counter once you get to the front of the line. Figure out what you want ahead of time. Don't hold up the line. People are hungry.

Seems like these guys have the baked goods dialed in. My first experience with their divine creations was because a generous co-worker of mine, Henry, brought a bunch in for us in the office one morning. After tasting them I was immediately physiologically addicted and had to find the source. Thanks, Henry!
author: Greg J.

description:
Stumbled across this place while exploring the Dogpatch.  This place is hands down the bakery to visit in San Francisco!  Everything they touch turns to golden flaky pastries or fantastically baked breads.  What's even better too is that this place isn't plagued with ridiculously long lines or immediately selling out of everything they have.  That being said, some of their items do sell out quickly but they'll usually have something interesting in stock for you if you're not particular about a specific thing.  I'll have to make more trips back here to pick up more of their amazing delights, but here's what I've had so far.

Everything Croissant:
I don't even like croissants, but I loved this thing.  Super flavorful with both the toppings, fillings, and croissant itself.  Really nice savory pastry.

Guava and Cream Cheese Pastelito:
Really good, I loved the guava filling, it really reminded me a lot of Portos.  The pastry itself is flaky and perfect in every way.  

Passionfruit Dough Bun:
Amazing donut that's been perfectly baked and goes really well with their passionfruit filling.  It tastes a lot like Hawaiian Passionfruit (lilikoi) butter so it's definitely richer than your standard jelly.  

Pistachio Blackberry Twice Baked:
Once again, don't like croissants, but this one haunts me with it's amazing flavor.  It's astounding that the croissant stays so flaky despite the jam on the inside.  The pistachios go really well with the blackberry too.  No blackberry seeds either which is a nice plus!
author: Bryson L.

description:
I never made it to the actual bakery, but the pastries they send to The Mill (which is nearer to my apartment) are delicious!

Why 4 stars then?  Because when I inquired with them via instagram, about one of their pastries that I love, they never replied.  And on their website, there's just no contact e-mail.  

Still though: delicious.
author: Valerie T.

description:
OMG I love their pastries! Why do you have to be so far away from meee, Neighbor Bakehouse?!? :( 

I've only been here twice - but I will definitely keep coming back for their yummy stuff even if it takes me an hour on MUNI to get there (SFans would definitely understand the pain here :P). So far all of the pastries I have tried are good! To name the few : Chocolate Claw, Passionfruit Doughbun, Ginger Pull Apart, Guava n Cheese Pastelito, etc etc etc I can't remember. Even my picky hubster agree that their stuff are awesome! It's a no-brainer on why Neighbor Bakehouse was voted to be the best bakery in California.

Thanks to Neighbor Bakehouse to mess up my clean-eating lifestyle! *pssttt, but I don't mind :D*
author: Priscillia I.

description:
I'm in love with the pistachio blackberry twice baked croissant! Well, I love croissants in general but I think of this place when I'm craving croissant. Another favorite is the ginger pull-apart. When I'm feeling something savory, I'd get the smoked salmon croissant.

There's usually a line rain or shine, but the line moves quickly. Not a lot of parking around the area and they'll only have a few tables out when it's sunny, so I usually get stuff to go rather than eat there.
author: Diana C.

description: I love this place. Very friendly staff. Great vibe and most importantly amazing baked goods. It's hard to pick out just a few but I'll try: kimchi toast, saurkrut crossiant, guava cheese pastry, pistachio raspberry crossiant, sour dough sandwich bread. Their cappuccino is definitely better than average but is a bit inconsistent.
author: Maya R.

description:
Seriously, this is as good as it gets! 
- Plenty of street parking around on the weekend
- Line moves pretty quickly
- Amazing selection of pastries and coffee. I got the sauerkraut smoked chedder peppadew tart and it was incredible. Also tried the ginger pull-apart which was amazing! 
- Plenty of outdoor seating and such a great vibe in the place 

Most definitely 100% will be back!
author: Priya B.

description:
Yum, what a delicious bakery. We came on a Saturday morning just before 9AM and there was no wait. There's no indoor seating, but the outdoor seating gets morning sun and it's lovely - just bring a jacket as it can be windy. My cappuccino was really great as well. Only downside to the place was that the service was not friendly.

Street parking was easy to find close by.
author: Kendra N.

description: Such a cute little bakery! The oat milk latte's and guava and cheese pastelito's are lifeeee.
author: Audrey H.

description:
THIS. Forget Tartine, Holmes, B. Patisserie, or any of the other big names - this is the secret treasure you're looking for. I've come here several times, and this is the only bakery that has never let me down. Everything is good, and many things are great. One of the few 5 stars I would give, because it's one of the few places I would actually outright recommend to a visiting friend. I actively seek this place out, and I'm still looking to explore more of their menu, particularly on the savory side since I haven't explored that as much yet. Personal standouts for me would be their croissants(any of them really, but you can't go wrong with their signature pistachio-blackberry), the guava & cream cheese pastelito, and the cinnamon almond bostock. Their pastry layers are superb!

I also like the open kitchen aspect of it - it gives off a homey vibe, with reasonable pricing to match. If you're in the area, I'd definitely say to give it a whirl! You won't regret it.
author: Edward R.

description: So good. Go for the savory ones, they're the standouts. One has sauerkraut in it, definitely try that one! Pro socialite tip: bring these to your hosts' house for dinner instead of wine. They will appreciate having a bomb breakfast waiting for them the next morning, and you will def move at least one rung into their inner orbit with this stealth move.
author: Doug W.

description: Absolute best croissants ever! So light and flakey! My favorites are the smoked salmon, and the smoked trout.
author: Aj C.

description:
This is a really cool bakery, located in the heart of the dog patch.  I came here with the girlfriend, so I ended up trying 3 different things.  I ordered the lox croissant w/ cream cheese.  I really liked it at first, but it has seeds on both sides of the croissant (maybe sesame seeds?), which got overwhelming.  I never had seeds on a croissant before, so maybe it's just a personal sentiment.  

My girlfriend ordered the ginger pull apart, which was really good.  It reminded me of the butterfly cookies.  I tried her pistachio blackberry croissant, which was just all right to me.  It was sweet and nicely toasted, but the best part was the jam in the middle of the soft bread. 

I wish they didn't run out of their best selling items though.  I got there around noon, and they were already sold out of many items.  Maybe they can try stocking more of the best sellers?
author: Eric L.

description: This was the best bakery I visited in San Francisco. The raspberry violet twice-baked brought tears to my eyes. It's like someone made a pastry just for me. Shout out to the manic pixie dream guy behind the counter. You guys know who I'm talking about.
author: Ama K.

description: Some of the best baked goods in SF with the absolute worst, and I mean worst service in SF. Employees are so rude every single time I've gone (which up until now has been weekly). Curly haired girl with 90s glasses especially needs an attitude check. ¯\_(ツ)_/¯
author: Brian F.

description:
This is pretty good.  The line out the front door moves along pretty quickly so don't be distraught if you get there only to find 20 others in front of you. 

They have some sweet pastries like hose topped with almonds.  Of course they have some plain pastries like an incredibly delicious croissant.  

They also have some savory which is what I think makes this place unique.  I tried the one with fish and cream cheese.  Also the ham and cheese one.   They were not my favorite but will have to come back and see what else they can do.
author: Marcus K.

description: Loved this bakery! Did not have to wait too long in line. Got the chocolate pudding pastry and the double baked raspberry hazelnut croissant. Both were delicious!
author: Nina M.

description: Many pastry options - I did enjoy the Ginger Pull-over and Everything Croissant. The only sad thing is the seating - yes it's outdoor but it's not under the sunlight and the seatings are limited.
