Basically there is one communal table (could sit 8 people?) where you share space with strangers (and being forced to listen to their conversation). Better grab your pastry and coffee to go somewhere else. If you fancy a relaxing sit-down environment to enjoy your breakfast, head to Vive La Tarte on Howard/7th St!
author: Shaz L.

description: This is my new favorite bakery in SF, sorry Arizmendi. We got a loaf of the sandwich bread, which we enjoyed for breakfast the whole week. We also indulged with the passion fruit macaroons, raspberry almond crosaint, and the chocolate pudding doughnut. Each one was perfect, worth the longer drive everytime!
author: Chris T.

description:
Awesome bake goods. My neighbor went into details about a new bakery in the neighborhood that had awesome pastries. I decided to walk to the Neighbor Bakehouse from my house and  check out and try a pastry. 
It was nice to walk into a authentic bakery with down-to-earth employees and customer service that was excited to see you order a pastry. 
I bought a chocolate chuck cookies and a pull apart ginger pastry. I was hooked after pulling away from my ginger pastry. It's was light weight ginger baked into the pastry that had a good balance and not overwhelming with ginger. And the chocolate chuck cookies was delicious. 
Overall, I am happy to be living in a neighborhood that has a Neighbor Bakehouse.
author: Tanika G.

description:
I don't even like ginger, but the ginger pull apart was so good! I came here with a friend after having brunch in the area and thought I would walk out with only 1-2 things, but ended up carrying out a huge box. Unfortunately I was so full that I couldn't try anything right then and there, but even a couple hours later everything tasted great! I was a bit worried about the ginger pull apart, but it was amazing and I would definitely get it again (and so fun to eat). 

Another one of my favorites was their savory morning buns. I saved mine for the next day and put it in the toaster oven for a bit before work and it was perfect. I could probably eat one of these every single morning!! 

I also got a croissant (good but not as good as Tartine imo) and some blueberry tart thing (sorry, I forgot) - clearly not as memorable but would pass on these next time. 

There isn't much room inside the bakery - only enough to choose what you want and then pay. There are a lot of benches outside though so you can always enjoy your pastries there which is nice.
author: Megan K.

description:
I have been to this place last year. I tried the ginger pull apart( I normally hate ginger and alway skip them) , they was ok.

I heard a lot of compliments about this place, I decide to come back and try 6 different things
- 2 ham& cheese morning bun
- everything croissant 
- cinnamon almond bostock
- passion fruit bun
- butter croissant
- kimchee toast
Everything is super good!! No wonder!
author: Thancha N.

description:
Best croissant dough I've ever tasted. Standouts include the everything croissant and the twice baked (berry+nut) croissants.

But basically anything based on their croissant dough is amazing.
author: Chris M.

description:
Cute little bakery in Dogpatch. There's not much seating inside the shop, but plenty of seating outside on the patio.

Really liked their ginger pull apart ($3.75). There was pieces of caramelized ginger baked right into it, and the pull apart makes it fun to eat a piece at a time. The pistachio blackberry twice baked pastry ($4) was okay. I wish there was more pistachio and blackberry, and that it was more evenly distributed throughout the pastry.
author: Alice T.

description: Delicious and unique pastries and dangerously close to my work  Price tag is a tad high and not sure if I would wait in a long line but early in the morning is best because the line is non-existent and everything is fresh.
author: Crystal K.

description:
Yes. Yes. Yes.

Though I live less than a mile away, a trip to Neighbor Bakehouse is best reserved for weekends. Which means getting up early on a Sunday and walking over in the cold and fog.

But the baked goods are more than worth the effort.

Not much fancy San Francisco "stuff" on the inside. It's an industrial bakery with a storefront. In addition to baked goods, they also sell coffee. Clean, efficient, not really meant for brunching in the traditional sense. But if you must bite into your treat before hopping back in the car/on the T-line, there are some small tables/chairs outside.

The menu changes somewhat regularly and there are several options to choose from. When in doubt, order two treats per person and you can go halfsies. Took home a savory tart with ham and cheese, everything croissant, chocolate croissant, and some sort of brown butter muffin. All of which were thoroughly enjoyed.

I want one right now.
author: Abby S.

description:
Where do I begin with this place? I know - stop whatever you're doing, get in a car, über, or the T line muni, arrive at Neighbor and buy the ginger pull apart. This is my favorite pastry of all time. Why? It's a myriad of textures and flavors that evoke all the best aspects of perfect baked goods. The pastry is composed of croissant dough scraps pieced together and layered with sugar and crystallized ginger. Its got a bit of that super on trend kouign Amman swagger with twice the size and twice the textural variance. The top is light and airy like those awesome bubbles that form on the crust of a pizza. Inside it's doughy and soft, like the inner layers of a cinnamon roll or raised donut. The bottom gets a crazy crystalized sugar caramelization that sticks to your teeth like ginger taffy. The aroma is buttery with dancing ginger spice and is never too sweet or too spicy. It is perfection. 

And that's just one pastry!!

Neighbor doesn't get the shine of some of the hipper spots in the city but it deserves all the glory. Their croissants are perfect, and I've tried them all from plain to chocolate (claw) to everything (bagel) to salmon to blackberry pistachio. Flawless layers of fluffy flour and butter. They also have a wonderful sauerkraut tart and rotating veggie tarts that perfectly balance savory ingredients with a sweet dough. I have literally tried almost every thing this shop has to offer and have never been disappointed. 

They also offer whole loaves of bread, and recently I picked up a fresh sourdough sandwich loaf ($6) and made the best French toast of my life with it. Go to neighbor. You won't regret it. 

Note: normally a spot that offers little-to-no seating would get a slight dock in my book but I'm in the "pick up pastries in my PJ's and bring them home" camp rather than try to deal with the early morning dog patch fog camp.
author: Sean S.

description:
Wow. I think it's better than Tartine.

Update 2/ 18/17:
Yup, still better than Tartine. On a weekday the girls who 'man' the counter are great-friendly, smart, and gorgeous. That's a community service tip for all you tech dudes filling up the tech kennels in this area. 

Today there were only men manning the counter. Don't bother tech girls;  not so friendly, not so charming, not so smart. But they still provided the goods, which are amazing.

Ginger pull apart: yes
Smoked fish and nori: yes
Pistachio blackberry:  yes
Cherry almond:  yes
Mushroom tart:  meh ( greasy, couldn't taste any mushroom)
GF buckwheat/orange:  meh taste, but fluffy
author: El B.

description:
Everything here is buttery and flaky in all the best ways, whether it's a good old boring croissant, a melt-in-your-mouth mushroom tart, or a hardcore "let's put everything on it" croque madame. In other words, their pastries are awesome.

There's no seating inside, but if it's a nice day, you can hang out on the tables just outside. If it's one of those rare rainy SF days, you're a little out of luck, since there really isn't anywhere else nearby to hang out.

If Neighbor Bakehouse was actually my neighbor, I'd be so happy (and probably carb-overloaded). But unfortunately, the Dogpatch location is a bit out of the way -- and the hours are very morning heavy, so I'll have to settle for getting my butter fix on the weekends (and rare early weekday mornings when I make my way out to Dogpatch).

Start your day off right with some of the best pastries you can get in San Francisco!
author: Brittany C.

description:
MUST VISIT FOR PISTACHIO CROISSANT!

* (WINNER!) Pistachio-Raspberry Croissant in my book wins the award for best, unique croissant I've ever had! Incredibly delicious and addictive.
* Guava cheese - Pretty good, like what you'd expect, a little dry
* Croque madame - Not a fan of sourdough croque. Cool that there was a perfectly poached egg on top, but tasted better in theory.
* Nitro four barrel cold brew - Excellent
author: Jess C.

description:
Looking for a quick bite to eat before catching the 22nd St Caltrain, I found Neighbor Bakehouse and decided to give it a try.  At 10AM, there was a good crowd at the tables outside the store, so I knew I was at the right place.  Everything on the menu looked so good that I wanted try all the different pastries!  I really liked how they had a lot of sweet and savory options.  I ended up getting the chocolate bear claw, the mushroom tart, and the ham and cheese bun.  All three came out to $11, which I thought was pretty fairly priced for pastries.  All three were absolutely delicious and I ate 2.5 of them in one sitting!  

Chocolate bear claw - The buttery, slightly salty croissant juxtaposed against the chocolate was such a good combination.  The bear claw was flakey on the outside and soft and chewy on the inside like any good pastry.  The chocolate inside of the croissant was a really deep, dark chocolate, and you could really taste the quality of the chocolate.  It was delicious paired with coffee.

Mushroom tart -- This was my favorite out of the three!  The pastry was the same delicious pastry as the chocolate bear claw.  The tarte was very savory and had a ton of flavor.  The mushrooms were surprisingly really meaty.  The cheese was melted perfectly on top with little bits of that crispy, melted cheese on the pastry.  The manchego was a nice pairing as it was salty, creamy, but didn't overpower the tart.  I didn't really care for the sesame seeds-- they were messy and I didn't really like the flavor they added.

Ham and Cheese bun - I really liked this one too, but I thought the shape of the bun made it kind of hard to eat -- I would have prefer a croissant or tart shape instead.  The top half was entirely pastry, and then in the center of the bun was the cheese and ham.  It was hard bite into, so you ended up eating the bun in two halfs -- one with just pastry, and one with mostly cheese and ham.  The cheese and ham were good.  Salty, meaty, and richy, but cut with grainy whole mustard.  The middle of the pastry almost had this cheesy/gooey center.  

As with all good pastries, be prepared to make a huge flaky mess! There is only sitting room outside at a few tables, so you'll probably have to take your pastries somewhere else to eat.  Can't wait to come back to try more things on the menu!
author: Michelle W.

description: I was very excited to try this place after I got two rave reviews from friends I trust. Their baked goods are delightful, but I'm not ready to replace Tartine as my go-to fancy baked goods spot. My everything croissant was tasty, but nothing I'm desperately craving in the future. Blackberry and pistachio make for an interesting combo in a croissant, but not my fav. I'm afraid that maybe my expectations were set too high before going! Neighbor Bakehouse is still a good option if you're in the area!
author: Laura B.

description:
I'm so happy this place is just a couple of blocks from my doorstep. Best discovery ever. This is truly a neighborhood gem. The guava puff makes me weep every time, it is so good. Sauerkraut cheddar puff sounds very odd but it's one of my favorites. We like the tartines as well. 

They make everything in-house and fresh. Really, really excellent stuff, you can't go wrong with anything you see on the shelves!  The long line is worth it.  Buy extras to go, you won't regret it.
author: Evelyn C.

description: Crazy good cherry/buckwheat muffin with crunchies of some sort on top. This came out of left field & blew me away !!!
author: Henry K.

description:
Phenomenal. In the past two days, I have tried the pistachio-blackberry croissant, ham & cheese bun, ginger pull apart, and the everything croissant. The pastries are flaky and soft on the inside, and very fresh!

The sandwiches are on the pricier side at $10 each. I guess that should not be a surprise given we are in San Francisco!
author: Junaedy L.

description:
Just so happened to be in the Dogpatch neighborhood, after an pretty intense morning workout, so wanted to treat myself :) found this on Yelp and oh my goodness I could not have treated myself better. 

They close at 2pmish on Sundays, so I got there only minutes prior. All  the pastries sold out except 2 (luckyyyy) so I quickly snatched both. I haven't even finished paying yet before another couple walked in, and got their hearts broken. Ha! Suckers.

The first one is this almond caketart that the staff promised to be mind-blowing... and yes mind blown. I don't even know how to explain it. Its just really really really good. Its got a perfect crust. Not the crunchy dry kind. The good baked bread kind. 

The second one is this lime donut with cream filling and crunchy sugar sprinkles. So much fun textures with an amazing lime flavor, without the artificial aftertaste that sometimes comes with traditional key lime pies. Delicious.

Today has been the best day ever thanks to NB's pastries. #blessed
author: Katy Q.

description:
I've been looking forward to visiting Neighbor Bakehouse for a very long time because of the rave Yelp reviews! And now that I've been, I can safely say that they live up to the hype! Mostly. The short story is that anything that's majority croissant is amazing (5 stars!) and everything else is pretty good (maybe 4 stars). 

My boyfriend and I came early on a Saturday morning since I had read in some other reviews that they do tend to sell out! We ordered the pistaschio blueberry croissant, almond cinnamon "toast", a mango passionfruit doughp bun, and an almond latte. 

-Pistachio Blueberry Croissant: Their croissant pastry is superflak,  and the contrast between the slightly salty pistachio and the sweet but tart blueberry jam made it a very balanced and delectable pastry! Though, I was hoping for just a little more blueberry flavor! 

-Cinnamon almond Toast: Ahhh i wish they delivered on the cinnamon flavor. The almond was really, but the brioche bread just super special. Though I do love the accents of croissant they've worked into all their different pastries! This one in particular was much better having been toasted again at home. 

-DoughP Bun: The passionfruit mango filling was really delicious, but it almost seemed more like a dessert than breakfast! Reminded me of asian bakery cakes which are delicious, but not exactly a pastry per say... 

-Almond latte: Unlike a lot of pastry shops where espresso drinks suffer in quality and are a sad complement to the awesome pastries, Neighbor Bakehouse is one of the few exceptions! One of my favorite lattes i've had at an elite pastry shop.

Another plus was that parking was super easy and painless (great for those who aren't comfortable with the SF driving conditions). Already planning my next visit!
author: Tiffany K.

description:
A spin-off (former employee) of Tartine, this place is a hidden gem.  Having lived down the street for a year (they were indeed our neighbor), I would see these guys toiling away at 11pm at night.

In a city where most 'foodies' know about every little spot, Neighbor Bakehouse is one of the few places that my friend's have yet to discover, and it's their loss.  Ironically, many people order Neighbor bakehouse products throughout the city at various coffee shops, without realizing the true source (Sightglass, Fourbarrell, The Mill, and Contraband to name a few).

Both the chocolate and 'everything' croissants are exceptional and the ginger pull-apart will blow your mind.  The smoked ham and gruyere morning bun is also great should you need something a little more substantial.  The only downside is that they don't offer any indoor seating, though they do have a moderate amount of outdoor seating.  You should also note that they do have odd hours, Wednesday - Sunday and they're only open until 2pm (closed Monday and Tuesday).

If you've never stopped by, do yourself a favor, skip the line at Tartine and get over to the the Dogpatch.
author: Tom G.

description: Best bakery in SF by far. I love this place. The only issue now is that everyone is finding out about this place so on the weekends there is a huge line. Years ago this was not the case, but they deserve all the rave. Amazing spot! The ginger pull apart is fabulous as is the croque Madame. All of the cookies and croissants are fabulous as well.
author: Melissa D.

description: Awesome place and staff was great.. Definitely going back and would recommend this place to anyone. Oh!! Peanut butter cookies are delicious
author: Paul O.

description:
This is my favorite bakery in San Francisco! I've tried a lot of things here and they were ALL good - plain croissant, chocolate croissant, almond bostok, chocolate chip cookie, ginger pull apart, and the list goes on. They even came around and gave bite sized samples of their croissants as we were waiting in line. 

There are a few tables outside that you can sit and eat after you grab your pastries. 
Don't come too late or they might be already sold out of their most popular items!
author: Elizabeth K.

description: This is my favorite pastry place in San Francisco. In my opinion, the pistachio Blackberry is my favorite. Even though it sounds weird, it is a delicious mix.The wait line only has about 10-15 people which only takes up to 10 minutes for the best pastry in San Francisco.Parking can be hard though.
author: Justin P.

description:
Croissants are pretty bomb.com. Neighbor bakehouse takes their baked goods pretty seriously. None are even on display at the counter. They just grab them off the racks from the pan that probably came out of the oven. All the baked goods are flakey, fresh, and tasty. Ham and cheese morning bun was an interesting savory twist. I thought they did a good job, although I would've liked even more savory ham and more cheesy goodness. 

Note that there is no indoor seating here, so it's best for grab and go. Most of the indoor space is reserved for all the baking. There are a couple of picnic benches outside and you pickup the coffee from a small window facing the patio. It can get pretty brisk and windy on a foggy SF day. Also, watch out for presents left on the tables by the birds.
author: Audrey L.

description:
I traveled far and wide just to be able to try this bakery... Well... Not that far... But still a good 45 min ride from across the city just so I could try the ham and cheese morning bun and see if this place was worth the hype. 

We came here at 9am on a Thursday with only a few people in line. They don't have tartine lines, but make sure to get here before 10am so you could get the good stuff.

Highlights: 

Croque Madame- I honestly have no words for this... This was absolutely amazing. It's basically a piece of sourdough with ham, cheese, caramelized onions and a soft poached egg on top. Eat this while it's hot: I would gladly travel from my humble abode in the Richmond district all the way to dogpatch if it meant I could get this again

Ham and Cheese morning bun- Smoked ham was too salty for me but the bun itself was flaky and buttery. 

Pistachio blackberry twice baked croissant- Is that pistachio creme inside? Very good balance of flavors. Luckily it is sweet but not too sweet!

Ginger pull apart- Tastes like a butter croissant and has that burnt caramel taste (if that makes sense). Reminds me of monkey bread by the way you pull it apart.

I tried other things such as the chocolate claw, cinnamon almond bostock, etc but these were the highlights. I will for sure be back!
author: Guilliana J.

description: The buttery and flaky croissants rate with Arsicault but it is the ginger pull apart that makes this place exceptional! Perfectly concocted with just a hint of ginger. The outdoor seating, the delicious coffee, and the friendly and prompt service combine to make this my to choice in SF. As a bonus, parking is available right out front on weekends.
author: Louis G.

description:
Croissant perfection in a small bakery located in the dog patch area. On thanksgiving morning the wait was about 5 minutes. Inside all of the fresh baked goods for the day are on display. We ordered some butter croissants, a chocolate claw, a pistachio almond croissant, and the ginger snap pull apart bread. 

The croissant was world class. A glistening, flaky exterior yields to an airy interior with each bite. The flavor is buttery and complex. The chocolate claw was similar but had firm bites of chocolate that were not overwhelming. The other sweet pastries were not overly sweet but still delicious. Overall, a fantastic bakery for croissants.
author: Aaron C.

description: Thanksgiving day pick up.  First time here.  Apple pie and pumpkin pie were delish.  I also ordered several smoked salmon, ham and gruyere, everything croissants, apple hand pie and purple potato.  The pastries were flaky, sesame seeds gave a nutty flavor but the filling was a little skimpy.  A must try st least once.  I would go back for the pies.
author: Nina I.

description:
Wow Wow Wow

Ginger pull apart - for the win
Pistachio blackberry - scrumptious
Veggie tart - sublime
Plain croissant - best in the city!!!

Overall thoughts

One of the best pastry shop in SF!
author: Eddie W.

description:
Some of the best pastries I've had. Favorites include:
Passionfruit doughnut bun
Pistachio blackberry twice-baked croissant 
Ginger pullapart 
Cinnamon almond bostock
author: I Fan L.

description:
Tried 3 things so far and here are the ratings : 
1- croissant : 5/5 best in SF 
2- veggie pastry: 3/5 
3- coffee: 2/5. 


Coming back for the croissants.
author: Ahmad A.

description:
I came to Neighbor Bakehouse on the recommendation of my girlfriend who is a baker for Craftsman and Wolves and was highly impressed!

I think I was a little surprised that this is the straight up bakery - they don't have any seats inside but they do have some benches out front. Most people grab and go.

Everything here as everyone has mentioned is fresh and delicious. The pastries and desserts are all amazing. I was also pleasantly surprised with the Macarons- super cripsy and thick outside but the inside was dense, chewy and amazing!

Overall - can't go wrong with anything here and it's joined the ranks of my favorites next to Mr. Holmes and Craftsman and Wolves!
author: Veronica S.

description: My favorite bake store. I have been going to this place since it was opened. My favorite: the everything croissant for the savory pastry and the pistachio twice bake for the sweet pastry. Don't get me wrong all their pastries are good the two mentioned are just my personal favorites. In case you are wondering, this place is better than Bounchon Bakery in Napa. Line can be long on the weekend but it usually move fast.
author: Y K.

description:
I work around here, so I'm glad that I can pop in during the latter half of the week when I'm needing a sweet morning fix without the line being as long as some other of the more celebrated bakeries in the city. I'm hesitant to write a review in fear of the line becoming longer, but I also love this place too much NOT to tell the world how good it is and the service is so speedy the line always goes quickly.

THE CHOCOLATE PUDDING DOUGHP BUN has enticed my taste buds time and time again. The outside layer is a perfect combination of chewy, crunchy, and sweet, while the inside is fluffy and light. All of a sudden, BAM. You get to the middle, to the main attraction.. The chocolate pudding. Tears of joy flow down your face and suddenly you feel like you truly can conquer the day's mundane yet exhausting tasks. Really. It's so amazing. If I were rich (and had a better workout regimen) I would eat one every morning.

I'm also set out to try all of their other pastries, but of the ones I've had I prefer sweet to savory. The savory pastries are all delicious (shoutout to my fave, the ham and gruyere morning bun) but the sweet ones always come out on top for me. The cinnamon almond bostock and twice baked pistachio blackberry croissants are tied for 2nd place in my heart. The only things I wished were different about Neighbor would be 1) bigger cups for lattes and 2) being open on Mondays and Tuesdays. Nothing would make a Monday morning better than a giant latte and a pudding doughp bun.
author: Jenny L.

description:
Got 6 items and my favorites were the butter croissant and chocolate claw.  Tender, buttery, flaky pastries, yum. 
The ham and cheese morning bun was good.
The middle of the pistachio blackberry croissant, where the pistachios are, was tasty - the edges not as flavorful and a little drier.
The veggie tart was OK.  A bit more salt would have improved. 
Didn't like the Everything Croissant - the onion was over-powering.
Short wait on a weekday, 10:30am.  Parking was difficult.  Few seats, outside only, so best to get order to-go.
Too bad they had run out of the mushroom tart and ginger-pull apart.
author: Lynn M.

description: Outrageously good! If you feel like savory, the mushroom tart is bonkers. For sweet, it's ginger all the way! Though regular croissants are also superb  - and the coffee is great, too!
author: Be F.

description: IMO the best bakery in SF. I used to work around the corner from Neighbor Bakehouse. That was a great period of my life :P I wish they had more locations or that more coffee shops in the city carried their pastries. I have tried a few items on their menu, my favorite is still the Almond Bostock. Pure perfection! If you enjoy baked goods, make sure you hit this one up. You won't be disappointed :)
author: Angel C.

description: The Rasberry-hazelnut twice baked bread was our favorite & the ham/cheese croissant was good also.
author: Rowland W.

description:
Oh my goodness, this place reminds me why food in SF is so special. I've had this place bookmarked on my to-visit list forever, but never been able to make it out. Then, my dear, beloved sister (bless her heart) brought back pastries from Neighbor Bakeshop and they were ahhh-maaazing. 

I tried the ginger pull-apart bread, pistachio blackberry twice-baked croissant, and a pomegranate coffee cake. The ginger pull apart bread was good, but a little bit on the sweet side because of the caramelization. 

The pistachio blackberry croissant was wonderful and I loved the pistachio filing. I'm a fan of almond croissants in general and was more than satisfied by this other nut-based variation. I'd totally get this again. 

My favorite of the three was the pomegranate coffee cake. The crumb topping wasn't too sweet, and there was a cheese filling in it that complemented the fruitiness perfectly and reminded me a little bit of the guava cheese rolls I love from Porto's in LA.

Thankful to have found this SF gem!
author: Rachel L.

description: The hype is real, one of the best bakeries I've been to anywhere. Had the ginger pull-apart, croque madam, and a few more. All were amazing. Just wanted to do my part and help keep this place at a perfect 5 stars, because months after leaving SF, I still think about what I had here.
author: Nam D.

description: Oh my... the pastries here are heavenly. I go to Dogpatch solely for Neighbor Bakehouse. Get the cinnamon pull-apart and a latte, and enjoy on their outdoor patio.
author: Tess H.

description: New find to add to my favorite bakery list! I loved the variety of sweet treats, my iced latte, and friendly customer service. Next time I go back I'll try the savory options.
author: Josie C.

description:
I have been here many times for normal pastries and they're all amazing (my favorite is the mushroom tart). But now I need to say how delicious their Thanksgiving pies were! We bought the pumpkin and the pear persimmon ginger black sesame pies. I knew the latter would be great with that combination of ingredients but I usually buy the Marie Callendars pumpkin pie for Thanksgiving which I think is great but after eating Neighborhood Bakehouse's, I think we'll have to always buy pies here for the holidays! The crust had many thin layers and I think I tasted ginger in the pumpkin pie that really made it special.

Regarding the other pie, there were lots of pears and persimmon inside with a great ginger taste. The black sesame was in the crumble which I could taste but it's not a strong flavor in comparison.
author: Laura K.

description:
Even though I was stuffed from brunch down the street, I rarely find myself in the Dogpatch and wanted to try out Neighbor Bakehouse. There was a short line, which gave me just enough time to study the Yelp photos and determine what to order.

We got one Ginger Pull Apart to share and everything else in the bakery looked delicious as well. In a way, the Ginger Pull Apart was like a glorified croissant. It tasted like pure heaven (aka butter) in the mouth. I did expect the ginger flavor to be more prevalent and spread out throughout the pastry, not just in the "core" section of it. This is the type of bakery every neighborhood would be lucky to have.
author: Yi Z.

description:
OMG best croissants in SF. Puts Tartine to shame. Shame shame shame.

Baked to a nice uniform brown color. The outside has a crispy, flakey, thin crust that gives way to soft, tender, buttery inside. I'm not sure how they can cook it so uniformly and to the perfect done-ness to achieve this without any burnt bits. 

Since it's only open in the mornings you'll probably be able to get one fresh - EAT RIGHT AWAY. Though still good hours later the crust will no longer have that crispy, flakey texture. You must get it from the source.

I got the ham and cheese morning bun to go for later and it was tasty but obviously not as great as my fresh croissant.

If I lived closer I'd be here almost every day.
author: Jean K.

description:
Make no mistake, Neighbor Bakehouse's chocolate croissant was one of the best things I've eaten. Like ever. Say good bye to any form of diet too.  The flaky deliciousness of their pastries isn't limited to just croissants.  The savory Ham & Cheese morning bun I ate was equally flaky and delicious. What's more is that there's a delightful friend who pours De La Paz coffee to go with your delicious baked items.  I will be returning to complete a mission: eat all the things at Neighbor Bakehouse.

Oh, and they make bread too.  As if you really needed another reason to check this place out.
author: Lisa I.

description:
Fresh pastries around $3+ each. The Croque Madame toast was delish. Runny egg and meaty. Fairly large slice to justify the $4+. 

Outside seating available and lines move fast.
author: Julie L.

description:
So I have been waiting to post my review of Neighbor because I never actually went to their storefront before! 

Alas last Saturday in the rain me and my gal pals decided on getting brunch treats here while going to nearby Philz to sit and nosh.

The croque madame was bomb! The mushroom toast was bomb! I highly recommend getting all their savory options and wished we got the kimchi toast too! I have previous tried their passionfruit filled croissant thingy, choco chip cookies, ginger pull apart, and probably something else I can't remember. 

Service is attentive and fast. Only outdoor seating available.

Will definitely be coming back soon! SO DELISH!
author: Angela D.

description:
What does good food and good sex have in common? 

Besides the obvious 'gasms, they can be incredibly life-changing. And, if your sex life blows...no worries, B.O.B has your back! Battery Operated Boyfriend that is. 

When I read that owner of Neighbor Bakehouse (Spruce and Tartine alum) makes the best croissants in the city, I had to validate this for myself (his goods are also available at various coffee shops like Sightglass, Fourbarrel, Contraband, etc). 

Neighbor Bakehouse softly opened last week with limited hours (Monday - Saturday 6:30 am to 11:30 am-ish) so check their fb page for updates: http://bit.ly/1IYIKk8. CASH ONLY until February 2015. 

Eagerly arriving at Saturday at 7 am, I was disappointed to see only about 8 selections on the racks. After the two customers in front of me left and it was my turn to order, a rack of fresh, hot of the oven croissants came rolling out. It was kismet. 

Come to find out, they only have a limited selection because they bake as they go so your pastry is nice and warm when you get it. Currently, there's no menu, description, or price tags. The cashier will explain all the selections available which may vary throughout the morning. I was told fresh bread is available at 10 am. 

I ordered 8 items: 3 butter croissants, 2 mushroom & manchego croissant tarts, 1 smoked cheese & spicy kraut croissant 1 squash & kale croissant tart, and 1 hazelnut financier for $25: http://bit.ly/1yhnanv.

As I walked through the door with warm box of croissants in tote, the smell of freshly baked, buttery goodness waft in the air and woke Mr. NSS up from his sleep. We sat there in bed indulging in the various croissant and croissant tarts. With the each bite, the delicately crunchy exterior lightly shattered making way into the soft, buttery fluffy layers. Best croissants in SF? Yup. 

The Mushroom & Manchego Croissant Tart was my absolute fav: http://bit.ly/1uitINu! It was like the love child of a cheesy mushroom pizza and wonderfully buttery layered croissant. Even more delicious with the sprinkling of toasted sesame seeds. Foodgasmic was one word to put it. Life-changing is another...

Mr. NSS fell back asleep while I laid in bed watching my awesomely bad lifetime movies. 

"More croissants...", he mumbled. I checked and he was still asleep. He never sleep talks. 

Croissants so phuckin' good you dream about it in your sleep? Yup, that's Neighbor Bakehouse.
author: Cherylynn N.

description: Modest in size and eminently cool, Bakehouse is the best bakery/patisserie in San Francisco. Yes, better than Tartine. The sauerkraut croissant could solve any franco-germanic war in one delicious bite.
author: Arbit A.

description: I have had this bakery bookmarked for over a year & I finally got a chance to go here for breakfast and I was NOT disappointed. We ordered chocolate pudding bun, cinnamon almond bostock, ginger pull apart, butter croissant, chocolate chunk cookie, chocolate claw, chocolate pudding pie & chocolate croissant. My family & I loved every single item we had ordered. After we were done with breakfast, We went back in & got a few cinnamon almond bostock, ginger pull apart & cookies to go.
author: Halina N.

description:
It took me a long time to remember to go to Neighbor Bakehouse on one of the two half days that is is actually open. Today was that day. On my way back from dogpatch I got off at the 20th street stop and picked up a box with one of of almost every type of pastry they had. 

The shop itself has almost no room for customers so the line very quickly wraps around out the door. It does move quickly though and they are smart in having the coffee service on an exterior window.

For my tastes the pastries varied in quality. I'll just go down the list with ratings but I will say that I was blown away by the pistachio blackberry croissant and underwhelmed by the mushroom tart that everyone mentions in their reviews.

Chocolate claw - 2/5
Pistachio Blackberry Twice Baked Croissant - 5/5
Bostock w/ Almond Frangipani - 4/5
Ginger Pull Apart - 4/5
Coffee Spice Cake - 2/5
Hazelnut Financier - 3/5
Mushroom Tart - 3/5

Overall, this is a great bakery with some really unique items. The hours suck but it is definitely worth a stop if you're randomly in the area on a wednesday or saturday morning. "I'm a fan."
author: Mark O.

description: Oat-milk latte with friends on a Saturday morning... mmmmm mmmmm! Make note the place is closed on Monday's.
author: Fabiola V.

description: Pricey but delicious!!! Financiers are great for your gluten free people. Bread is the best in town (IMO)!
author: Urban S.

description:
Greg Mindel is a master of laminated doughs and pastries, and it shows in every single product produced at Neighbor. The savory pastries were delicious - including the OG regular croissant, filled with buttery goodness and flaky, shattering layers. The everything croissant and ham and cheese morning bun were flavorful and hard to stop eating too. 

As for sweet, my favorite was the pistachio blackberry twice baked croissant, but the bostock and pastelito and macaroon were all amazing too. The chocolate pudding inside the little dough ball thing was killer as well. 

Thanks Greg for a great experience and very full bellies!
author: David B.

description:
After coming back from Vegas and having a very disappointing experience with a so-called patisserie there, I was happy to get back to some serious pastry eating here in the bay area. Today my travels took me to Neighbor Bakehouse. Now, I was thinking before I sampled their goods, this was probably going to be a 4 star experience. Wrong.

Neighbor Bakehouse is definitely 5 star material. 

Relying on previous reviews, I settled on the pistachio croissant and the ginger pull. I also got the apple pocket. All were excellent. Their pistachio croissant has that great buttery flakiness that's a requirement for us pastry snobs. The ginger pull reminded me of an extra large Kouign Amann, ha-ha, flaky and buttery. The apples in the little pocket were cooked all the way through, the way I like them. If you like the classic apple pie, the pocket will be your cup of tea.

Frankly, I'm just blown away at the level of pastry excellence in the city. All I can say, if you open up a bakery/patisserie in the city, you better have your act together.
author: Anthony W.

description:
these were sooo good warmed up/toasted if you cant get to it fresh :9

- chocolate pudding doughp bun: this is my most faaave...that delish chocoloate pudding and fab crust made such a grrreat combo!
- passionfruit doughp bun: this was good and tart
- ginger pull-apart: this was really good...not overly sweet
- German Coffee Cake: yummy vanilla custard, blackberry poppy flower jam, and streusel atop a sweet dough brioche. 
- Raspberry Violet Praline Twice-Baked Croissant: this was ok...liked the hazelnuts. soaked in vanilla syrup, filled with a caramel hazelnut cream, raspberry violet jam, topped with hazelnuts, cherry powder and powdered sugar. 
-Oat Chocolate Coconut Cookie ~ mmm yummm! an "everything"cookie with nuts, shredded coconut, rolled oats, Valrhona white and dark chocolate and sprinkling of sea salt.

- ham and cheese morning bun: this warmed and cheese goodness was fab
- veggie tart: all i remember was cherry tomatoes but it was yum! a savory tart prepared
with California's freshest seasonal produce, goat and manchego cheeses, béchamel sauce, seeds.
- chorizo potato herb turnover: this was a good savory
author: she q.

description:
Happy to finally have a delicious bakery in the neighborhood. Although hours are limited, I alway try to grab a chocolate claw which is aaahhmazing (I'd prefer it over Tartine's!) or the ginger pull apart which is perfect to take with on a morning stroll.

I've tried a few of their savory pastries like ham and cheese morning bun but prefer sweets so I can't comment too much on that. It was good and my husband enjoyed it. Would I order it again? Probably not.

I haven't had the chance to try their breads but plan to the next time I stop in.
author: Tiffany L.

description:
I work in this area so this is such a wonderful addition. Surprised to discover a new pastry shop during my lunchtime walk. I was looking through the window and the employees insisted that I enter. Inquired on when they opened and everyone was very warm and friendly. They offered for me to pick a pastry but I told them that I hadn't brought my wallet but they insisted that I take a couple of things but promise to come back. It was so nice.

They gave me the Everything Croissant (savory) which had cream cheese inside and the Pistachio and Almond Pastry (sweet). OMG. I've never had flavors like them. They were amazing. The croissant was light, flaky with a type of oniony cream cheese filling. It was refreshing to find a savory croissant for a change because I prefer more savory flavored pastries (such as gougeres).

It's a blessing and a curse (for my waistline) to have such a delicious pastry shop close to work!
author: Viyada S.

description:
Best savory tart I've ever had. The only bakery in the city where I'd recommend any savory baked good over a sweet one (the sweet ones are also amazing though). I'd recommend the chorizo-onion-cheese tart - light, not too oily, but packed with delicious flavor.

Seating is only picnic tables outside so hopefully it's not too chilly, otherwise I'd recommend grab and go.
author: Jeffrey Z.

description:
Erm...AMAZING!!!!!!!!!
I have to be honest, I've walked past this location a number of times and never realized it was there. I happened to be going past Saturday morning with my husband, when we noticed this long line of people. Being the inquisitive people we are, we moved closer to investigate, and were enticed further by the smell. I had some friends to meet, but figured we would line up anyway. It actually didn't take long to get to the front - I just wanted a butter croissant, so I sent my husband in to pick what he wanted. He came out with kimchi toast. My plan, since I was about to have lunch, was to save my croissant till after lunch, then the plan was just to eat the end of it and save the rest...well, let me tell you, that plan went right out the window once I tasted the end! I have been on a quest recently to find the perfect croissant - this one hit every point. The outside was crisp and flaky, the inside was buttery and soft with layers of deliciousness. The one bad thing, I ate it way too fast. 
I also tried the kimchi toast - soooooo good! And I'm usually not a fan of kimchi!!
So, needless to say, I brought my friends back here after lunch. They too were also impressed!
Aside from the amazing food, the staff here are soooo ridiculously nice! I find at some one off places like this, especially when they have rave reviews, there tends to be an arrogance that goes with some of the staff - there was not even a whiff of that here. They all seemed genuinely nice and happy to be there. 
When I got home, I did some research on the place and the owner, and I could be mistaken, but from the pictures it would appear that owner was one to actually serve us that day - super super nice! 
I live down in San Jose, but would more than happily trek up to the city to go this bakery. Do yourself a favor and check it out - you won't regret it!!!!
author: Elle B.

description:
Yes. 

This is one of my top 3 bakeries for a nice, relatively cheap breakfast. We had the veggie tart, pistachio pastry, and chocolate filled morning bun. All were delicious and super filling. This is definitely a great place if the weather is good to sit outside and chill!
author: Akshaya V.

description:
it's been over a year (maybe two) since i had my first taste of the decadent deliciousness that is neighbor bakehouse and i'm actually quite surprised to realize i never reviewed it in all this time. but having just finished a ginormous slice of their toothsome kimchi toast and somehow also consumed their perfect guava and cream cheese pastelito, i am glad i never reviewed them. because now i can happily report that neighbor bakehouse is one of those remarkable eating establishments that has only become better since i first tried it. 

other amazeball items include their everything croissant (f-ing genius!), the mushroom MANCHEGO tart, the sauerkraut peppadew tart, and their absolutely flawless nitro cold brew. seriously the coffee is incredible, i am a cream and sugar girl but with this magical drink, its somehow not necessary. so smooth, so creamy, so wow.

i cannot recommend this place enough. and i don't have to. five stars in SF? come on now!
author: Archana P.

description: Stood in line for 30 minutes for the raspberry croissant, morning bun and one other item that got devoured so fast I forgot what it was called. Absolutely delicious morning buns if you can't decide what to get. I was greedy since I had to stand in line and decided to get more than I could eat. No regrets though ! Luckily this place isn't nearby or else I would be a big fat kid !
author: Mel T.

description:
Best Baked Breakfast in the Bay Area. 

There is no way with a clean continuous I can give this gem less than 5 stars.

Everything here is the best you'll ever have accompanied with very friendly people. The bar has been set and going forward everything will be judged against this.

There is no parking anywhere around here.
author: Justin S.

description:
No frills kind of place. All about the baked goods and coffee. My family and I just happened to walk past it after brunch at Serpentine and I am SO GLAD I got some goodies for later.

The ginger pull away was delish x 100. It stays crisp for hours after and it's buttery goodness. The ham and cheese bun was good, but I wish there was more cheese in it. The middle is just a big hollow space that I wish had more of something...anything....cheese? hahah 


I will definitely be back here. I must try their coffee and other creations that were screaming at me to "buy me. eat me. get me. consume me."
author: Jennifer T.

description: One of my favorite brunch spots in SF. They serve the most fresh and tasty pastries, breads and brunch items I've ever had from a bakery store. The staff is kind and friendly, their menu items are unique and mouth-watering delicious, their sour-dough breads are perfect and moist, and the only bakery I know in SF that serves "pastelitos de guayaba con queso"...YUMMM! You just have to try it out for yourself. Wish they were open later and all 7 days of the week!
author: Lissette I.

description:
I've been craving pastries a lot lately.  Decided to check out this place based on yelp reviews and I kinda know that area (I wouldn't get lost). 
EVERYTHING is so yummy.. I was in a short line around 10am on a Saturday.  my only complaint would be that I drank my coffee too fast and it was sooo good!  This review doesn't give a lot of info.. just go!
author: Regina B.

description: My wife found this local bakery a short drive from SOMA and in a part of town called Dog Patch. This has a perfect rating, which is rare. We decided to try it. One bite of any of their baked goods and you instantly know why they have a perfect rating. It really is that good. We tried the ginger pull-apart and the blackberry pistachio twice baked croissant. By far two of the best pastries I have ever had. Every bite was sumptuous and filled with perfectly balanced flavors. This is a must-try bakery. And, the staff are very friendly. Great place, delicious food.
author: Alidad V.

description:
This place is awesome. They sell freshly baked, fantastic tasting pastries pulled right out the oven for very reasonable prices ($3.50-$4.00, $6.50 for a delicious croque madame).

Highly recommend the chocolate pudding dough ball - effectively a no hole, dense donut with chocolate pudding in the center. Saw lots of people eating/heard great things about the croque madame as well.
author: Amy G.

description: This place is delicious and unpretentious. I got a classic chocolate croissant and it did not disappoint
author: Susan T.

description: One of my favorite bakeries in the city! Comparable to the quality of b patisserie and Tartine manufactory, if not better imho. Pro tips: if you're craving something savory, get the ham & cheese morning bun. I feel like with dishes like this I'm worried there will only be a sliver of meat inside, but the ham in there is plenty and delicious. A good balance with the flaky croissant exterior and a perfect size for a morning bite. When you're craving something sweet, the blackberry pistachio twice baked croissant is delicious. It has the perfect amount of tart/sweet with the nutty crunch of the pistachio. My friend got the raspberry walnut twice baked and enjoyed that too. Can't recommend the drinks as they made a me a chai latte from concentrate that was way too spicy and kind of pricey ($4.50). Only limited outdoor seating and sometimes the line gets long (although it moves fast) on the weekends so get here early!
author: Cathy H.

description:
Wonderful savory snacks and tea latte.

Don't miss their hot ginger turmeric tea flavor...
author: Priyanka L.

description:
This bakery is LEGIT.

Unassuming and without the giant line or overly hipster interior of many other trendy bakeries - not naming any names here - Neighbor Bakehouse is the real deal. Their pastries, breads, and other breakfasty treats are a little bit creative and a lot delicious.

Here are some of my favorites:
-Croque madame - this sandwich is room temperature and not at all toasted like I typically like but it is still amazing. There is a tomato-based sauce that adds an some extra savory flavor, and the presence of both green onions and a generous allotment of ham make the $6.50 price point well worth it.

-Blackberry pistachio twice based croissant - yep, it is everything the description says it is and a little bit more. Toasted texture is perfect. This item is also available at Four Barrel.

-Doughp? I kept thinking this was a typo on the signage, but another Yelper told me it is actually intended as a play on the word "dope." Translation is delicious pudding filled brioche pastry that you can get in either chocolate or passionfruit varieties.

Hours on the business say "6:30am-noon(ish)" but I have been there past 2pm on multiple Saturdays now and they are still open and serving until they run out of merchandise (or when the food truck comes to take their excess to feed the needy).
author: Stephanie T.

description:
Now I can understand what Muslims must feel when they go on the Hajj to Mecca. I've been eating pastries made from here sold at Sight Glass for years, but this was my first time stepping foot within the mothership. Besides the best baked item mankind has ever invented, the Pistachio/Jam Croissant, I was also fortunate enough to try a warm Everything Croissant with its filling of cream cheese and onion. Upon digesting just half of one, I envisioned myself eating dozens and going out Leaving Las Vegas style. I also bought a Ginger pull apart because - ginger that's why. They also serve Lattes. Yah.

I love you NB.
author: Darin E.

description: Best kept secret - not for long. Everything is delicious. Unbelievably good pastries.
author: Erin W.

description:
The coffee 
the pastry 
the sandwich are  excellent
The quality are outstanding 
Different layers off meat in the sandwich are just perfect
author: Dan D.

description:
This place is amazing in every way! The baked good are to die for. I was visiting a family member @ the hospital down the street and was able to walk up to this place in the AM. They were friendly and had great suggestions for the box of goodies I brought back to the nursing staff.
    The everything croissant was perfect, the ginger pull apart was just the perfect mix of ginger & sweet, & the pistachio thing was just plain delicious. Thank you neighborhood bakery!
author: Mary W.

description: Omg. Best croissants ever! Especially the everything croissants! A bit pricey but still cheaper than tartine! Line starts pretty early but is totally worth the wait. Street parking only and there are tables for you to sit outside.
author: Mizzie C.

description:
Neighbor Bakehouse started as a popup in the Mr & Mrs space for about a year, eventually shutting down, much to my dismay. So, imagine my excitement when I heard they were actually getting a full brick and mortar shop!

I've been here more times than I'd like to admit since then, so, rather than boring you all with drab particulars about all their pastries, I'll just say this: everything is delicious, but they definitely excel in their savory pastries more than their sweet ones. The croissants are must-haves, and, for those with a sweet tooth, definitely grab one of the passion fruit custard filled pastries! I've seen these come in two different forms so far, but both have been delicious. Other notables include their ginger pull-aparts, cinnamon almond bostocks, mushroom tarts, and sauerkraut smoked cheddar tarts (trust me on this one, even if you dislike sauerkraut).

Get there before 11am and they should still have most things available. And either buy to go, or be prepared to stand around, as the limited outdoor seating does tend to be full.

***Accessibility Info***

Venue - The shop itself is just a little front area you walk in to and order from, so accessibility isn't really an issue. The seating outside is somewhat accessible: if you want to scoot in under the table, you'll have to move the benches first.

Bathroom - Didn't try them, but I'm not sure they have a public one.
author: Johnny W.

description: Line is a fraction of Tartine, the prices are better and the crossiants are tastier!
author: Ben B.

description:
I've read the reviews...blown away by the scrumptious descriptions....salivating...and DogPatch - once the ghetto- is so far...

So, the Tat guy in the chair at the salon, was raving about the high octane delicious pastries.
I listened. I plotted, planned and drove the heck over there for some of the very best yummiest calories I have ever enjoyed. 
Pull Apart - pull at my heart!
I shall return
author: Miami S.

description:
If I could give 6 Stars, I would. This place is amazing. Every pastry (and I purchased almost all of them while on a recent business trip with a conference nearby) was insanely good. I even brought a box full of pastries home on the plane with me. 

My favorites are the pistachio blackberry twice-baked and the croissant. I know it seems odd that a basic croissant could be my favorites but it is amazingly layered with flaky crust and butter while being perfectly baked. They have a chocolate pudding donut but I have missed it twice now, it always sells out so if you want to try it, go early.
author: Christy D.

description: Love, love, love this place. I got a box of goodness today for a colleague's birthday and we devoured each piece.  The chocolate pudding bun, butter croissant, ham and cheese morning bun, ginger pull apart and mushroom tart were among the favorites. Oh wait...I named everything I got!  The line out the door can be intimidating but it moves quickly. The staff is both super friendly and efficient. I will gladly inhale a pound of butter from Neighbor Bakehouse any day!
author: Mary H.

description:
Worth a trip from anywhere 

Absolutely fabulous, buttery, light and delicate. You'll want to have 1 of everything!!
author: Janet K.

description: I love this place! It should get five stars because of the quality of products but I can't due to the wait times. Seriously been here when there is only 5 people in front of me and it still takes 30 mins. After coming here close to 4 years you would think that they would realize they need a second point of sale system. What should take a only a few minutes take longer because there is  one person who can take your monies!  Love the product but not worth the wait.
author: Eddie E.

description: Unbelievable pastries and baked goods. Went on a rainy Saturday and they were friendly and not too busy but I can see how they might run out on a busy day. I highly recommend the "Everything" croissant which is quite unique.
author: Jordan C.

description: I go here every week the bakery is great but counter service was poor today!  The person packing the box paid no attention to how he packed the items so have off them either broke or fell apart, poor service!
author: Richard B.

description: The quality of the croissants is impeccable. I had a mushroom tart which was great but needed something like either garlic or chile to up the taste. It was very bland. The ham and cheese had more flavor. The smoked fish/cream cheese was OK but lackluster. The ginger pull apart was good but would love more ginger.
author: Robin L.

description:
I discovered this gem this weekend while dog sitting!! 

I had the croquet madame, ginger - almond pull apart and cafe americano. It was heaven! 

I had the "everything croissant" to go &  it's super delish!! 

The staff are friendly to me  &  the dog. 

FYI, they are only open Wed-Sunday.
author: ASIANDIVAH A.

description: I have this problem where I pretty much only write yelp reviews in the throes of ecstasy or the depths of rage. This is the first kind. I just had some berry and violet twice baked bread croissant thing and can't understand how I lived before.
author: Kate J.

description: I tried the pistachio and blackberry twice-baked croissant which was absolutely delicious. Staff is high quality, happy and very welcoming.
author: Elliot H.

description: One of my favorite bakeries in the city. Lovely sweet and savory offerings. Really cute space and nice seating outdoors. Worth the schlepp all the way to Dogpatch.
author: rik p.

description:
I never thought I would have a baked goods addiction problem until Neighbor Bakehouse opened by my house.  I can't even go a few days without getting the hazelnut butter cake bs even the few days they are closed M-T gives me hardcore anxiety.

I've had the hazelnut butter cake, veggie / sauerkraut and cheddar / mushroom tarts, croque madame, stuffed Nutella chocolate puff thing.....I know I have a problem but everything is SOOOO good!  Flaky, flavorful, butter filled goodness you won't be able to resist anything they bake.  Next on my list is the bread pudding which they don't always have.

Thank you for opening up such an amazing shop and for not judging me when I make binge purchases of hazelnut butter cake!
author: grace m.

description:
Are we in Portland? :-)

Nice unpretentious bakery focused on making good eats. 
Thankfully the lines are not as long... and I'm not the type to wait 2hrs for the best croissant in America or any Tartine extension.

It's not a value play, but if you're willing to drive to Dogpatch, you're obviously willing to spend a little more to try something different.

* nice outdoor bench seating
* pistachio blackberry twice baked croissant (never disappoints)
* ginger pull apart (sometimes a little dry but generally flaky)
author: Yohdaddy M.

description: Kimchee toast...I heart you!  It's a hearty portion, with kimchee and cheese sitting atop a thick multigrain (?) toast.  $5.  Oh how I wish we had a toaster oven to heat the cheese up.  I can only imagine how good that would be.  Nonetheless...I gobbled it up in no time.  This is the only time when having too many wonderful choices is a problem.  Looking at that lengthy menu, can I have one of each please?
author: Melinda Y.

description:
Fantastic bakery in Dogpatch. Every golden, flaky pastry of theirs is pure gold. The ham and cheese morning bun. The buttered croissant.  The veggie tartine.

Be warned seating is only outdoors on benches, but the food is on point.
author: Jason P.

description: Mmmmm!! I took my mom and niece here early on a cold foggy Saturday morning. Soooo glad I did! My mom loved her smoked fish croissant; my niece enjoyed her chorizo potato turnover; and my pistachio blackberry croissant was sheer perfection with a latte! I loved it that there was no queue when we arrived - maybe due to the early hour and fog. I'd definitely return to try their other goodies!
author: Eliz Y.

description: I made it a point to come to Neighbor Bakehouse after reading about their baked goods on the Eater SF blog. I had the Pistachio-Blackberry Twice Baked Croissant and it was outstanding. I also ordered an almond milk latte. I only had about 10 minutes, so I did order my items to go. Once I took a bite, I was hooked and I ate the entire croissant in about 4 minutes flat. My latte was delicious and the milk was very creamy and perfectly steamed. I will be coming back to try their other baked goods.
author: Melanie E.

description: Never been here and unfortunately came to the bakery after hours. There were very nice employees outside, eating, and they gave us a ginger pull-apart that they weren't going to eat. IT WAS AMAZING!!! Omg. Sooooo coming back here during hours and ordering everything. EVERYTHING. Totally come here, wait in the line and eat the food. YUM. Thank you again to the employees that gave us the pull-apart!!
author: Heather E.

description: Originally, I was skeptical/excited about this place because it had 5 stars and didn't want to completely hype myself up for this spot, but after eating 3 of their pastries I can confidently say that this spot is legit af. No lie, I think I could order anything here and be content with what I got because they're that good. Ordered a double baked croissant with raspberries, everything croissant and the croque madame. They know what the hell they're doing out here man. Give it a try and I don't think you'll be disappointed.
author: Alex L.

description: I'm glad this place is only couple of blocks away from where I lived. This is a great addition to the Dogpatch. I usually see a long line whenever I passed by so I went early this morning to try their pastries. OMG! They are so good and will definitely go back and try other pastries. I recommend the almond pastry. I think Mr. Holmes found a match.
author: mel m.

description: Quaint little bakery. Interesting combos of sweets and savories. Tried the Ginger Pull-apart Croissant and Potatoes Chorizo Puff Pastry Squares. Preferred the Ginger Croissant. Perfect, sweetness, texture, and chewiness. Definitely will come back to try more.
author: Tea V.

description: Creative bakery dishes prepared well. Both savory and sweet pastries are good. I had the Croque Madame which is a veggie, egg and ham on thick toast dish. Nice!
author: Brian C.

description:
The Neighbor Bakehouse Breakfast of Champions* includes:

GINGER PULL APART.  New favorite.  Sugary flaky goodness.
BOSTOCK.  Sprinkled with powdered sugar and slivered almonds.  Chewy texture.  Love.
CHOCOLATE CROISSANT.  Fun bear claw shape.  Does not skimp on the chocolate.  Good call.
MINI COFFEECAKE.  Muffin shaped.  Muffin top.  Awesome crumble.  More chocolate.
PISTACHIO BLACKBERRY CROISSANT.  Not a ton of fruit flavor.  Otherwise fine.  
Ham & Cheese Morning Bun:  Savory morning bun fun.  Poppyseed extravaganza.  Thumbs up.  

*Yes the Champions are fatties.  (Thanks Pastry Fairy!)
author: Amy C.

description: Neighbor Bakehouse is delicious!!! So so so good!! The queue at Tartine is a joke, so if you have a craving for delicious pastries, head to Neighbor Bakehouse. The queue moves fast and the service is fast and friendly. Try the ham and cheese morning bun, it's sensational! Literally all of it is good so take your pick!
author: Allie S.

description:
Worth a return?  I've already gained a waist size from the moment they opened.
Worth a 30 minute drive? YES.  Maybe better to walk so you don't gain a waist size.
Worth a flight?  Let me put it this way.  If you are closer to Ble Sucre in Paris, fly there.  Otherwise, go here.

Each bakery has a niche.  I feel Holmes Bake Shop and Craftsman are experimental and cutting edge.  But with Neighbor, he's been supplying local eateries with his legendary pastries for so long, everything is proven.  His creations not only sound interesting, but they are at the most basic level consistently delicious.  

Everyone goes crazy for the Everything Croissant or the Ginger pastry.  Those are good.  But I love the bostock (so intriguing that this far exceeds it's historical origination as a way to get rid of stale brioche bread).  And before Neighbor opened up, I have long been in love with the pistachio croissant, obtained at places like Sophie's Cafe.  When you bite into the pistachio croissant--warm--it's like those old peppermint patties commercials:  I am transported to Istanbul, to a quiet side street of the Grand Bazaar, with a petite cup of turkish coffee and . . . this perfect, exotic pastry.  

Let me give you some advice.  Don't go with too rigid an idea of what you should get.  This is the type of place you can go omakase.  Most important question for this type of place:  ask what just came out of the oven.  Be willing to wait around outside until something does come out of the oven.  Warm, newborn pastry = food orgasm.  Not the fake kind you see from the tired hosts on the Food Network.  This is the real thing. 

PS: They still satisfy greatly when they're not warm too.

Appreciate that it's pretty much a miracle to be able to get Neighbor Bake goods finally fresh from the oven.  Bravo, Neighbor Bakehouse team.  Bravo for not being snobby and elitist like some other bakeries.  Does Michelin give out stars to bakeries?  Because if they do, this place will absolutely get em.
author: Philip L.

description: Not much to say. I go here pretty much every day it's opened. The cashiers know what I usually get (bostock), I feel like I have a problem. So pretty much don't go here if you don't want to be sucked into the vacuum of pastries. I'm only writing this because I'm craving it and I'm waiting for Wednesday to go buy some. I need help.
author: Vinh T.

description:
Wow. Wouldn't say this is a well kept secret because there is usually a little bit of a line every time I'm here. Great pastries for an easy snack with coffee on the weekends. I always stop by here for a box of goodies when I'm headed to someone's house for brunch. 

My favorites so far are the ginger pull apart (very very good if you like cronuts/morning buns), the guava and cheese pop tart looking thing, and the cookies. Everything else I've tried is good but those are the most memorable. I love that they combine artisan French style pastries with unique San Francisco flavors. 

Decently priced, kinda out of the way/in the middle of nowhere, fast service and accepts cards. Would recommend.
author: Stine H.

description: Super cute bakery with tons of outdoor seating right on 3rd. Their pastries looked delicious..unfortunately was just coming back from ice cream and did not have the appetite to try one. Got an iced coffee. It was really smooth. Only minor quibble is I wished the iced coffee had a few ice cubes in it. The day was so hot and after a few minutes outside, the coffee tasted very lukewarm.
author: Yin H.

description:
THIS IS MY FAVORITE BAKERY. 

I got the ginger pull and pistachio blackberry jam croissant. I fell instantly in love. 

Can't wait to come back and try everything else here!

TIP: GO EARLY. Things will sell out. They close at 12pm.
author: Cindy M.

description: Looking at the posted pictures I had to come here. On a weekday it is impossible to find a parking and the parking spot to jump in and order to go is taken like forever. Finally made it on a weekday when I was off work and although I loved the customers and the park benches that you share with others; I was not impressed with the selections and expected more options, maybe when I showed up they were busy baking new batches.
author: Mehran A.

description: Neighbor Bakehouse goods are 5 STAR. Had some bites of bliss of my friends breakfast concoction/ensemble  (like a small pizza w/ an egg, sausage, veggies, cheese) Yum! And some of the legendary ginger/almond pull bread. It can be a busy joint, with many goodies selling out before 11a.m.
author: Matsuo U.

description:
Yes. Everything about this place is YES!!!! Before today I had never heard about a bostock.... but now my life has begun. The cinnamon almond bostock was light, melt-in-your-mouth, hint of cinnamon, perfection. I think it's the only time I've ever eaten a pastry slowly because I wanted it to last FOR-EV-ER (cue Sandlot clip). 

Honorable mentions go to the veggie tart & ginger pull-apart, which were fabulous. 

Sure, there was a line all the way outside to order, but it was a 10 minute commitment that is 100% worth it. 

The staff here are friendly, quirky, hard-working people. And they are great coffee baristas, too!!

The outdoor seating was kiddo and puppy friendly, and easy for groups of 4-6. Most groups shared tables easily with other groups. They have picnic tables that seat plenty and have a pretty quick turnover rate. 

Pro Tip: Sit in the middle of the benches... as you'll get the teeter totter effect if you sit on the end of a bench without someone on the other end!!!
author: Katie V.

description: NB baked goods are by far some of the best i had in a long time. Highly recommend. Ginger pull apart - could stand some more ginger, but even as is probably in the top 3 things i've eaten this whole week.
author: Oleg H.

description: Words cannot describe how awesomely awesome this place is! When we were here, we ordered like 5 things. I can't remember exactly what they were. And it really doesn't matter because we loved all of it!! The fluffiness mixed with the perfect amount of crisp in each bite is enough to not only lure you in but make you come back for more!
author: Karen L.

description:
Every week I face several battles of resistance that start on Wednesday. I wake up, scoot to work, and hold this internal debate while en route on Cesar Chavez. Go, don't go. Go, don't go. 

Today I lost that battle, which means I actually won. I succumbed to my all time favorite croissant ever in this world: the sauerkraut cheddar peppadew, a flaky, buttery, flavorful packet of utter bliss and latticed deliciousness that always ends too soon. 

I also love their chocolate and regular croissants. From the delicate, intensely intricate layers which speak to their expert technique to the rich golden hues and subtle sheen of their exteriors, it's clear these babies are baked with lots of love and care (and top quality butter and assorted ingredients).

These croissants are so amazing, I like to just get a regular cuppajoe - hot or iced - to wash them down. 

Everyone is so friendly here and clearly passionate about their craft. Thanks for opening your doors here in the Dogpatch near my work. Even if that means I have to work out more...and occasionally lose -- but really win -- a few weekday battles. :)

*addendum. Ha, so good I forgot I already wrote a review! my bad for the dupe!
author: T L.

description:
All you need to say is "BEST SELLER" and I wonder WTH is so special about whatever product that you are trying to peddle.  I'm not a band-wagoner, as much as someone who wishes to be the devil's advocate.

Unfortunately, for me, there is really no argument here (at least none that I can generate).

Well, maybe that the Pistachio Blackberry Croissant was just too good and that I will no longer be able to fit into my skinny clothes.  WOE IS ME.

I didn't try anything else.  They had me at "BEST SELLER" and why?  Because CARBS.

xo
author: Hiromi N.

description:
What a delight! Big, creative, beautiful and well-baked pastries. Great cappuccino. 

No indoor seating (only a few benches outside)
author: Diane W.

description: The ginger pull-apart. I didn't think I'd like it as much as I did. It was great to eat on the go, walking back to my place. Plus, it was easy to "share" and give others a taste without letting them steal too much. Built in portion control ftw. The line moves pretty quickly so try to know what you want by the front, but the staff can always take a breather to give you their recommendations.
author: Kimberly C.

description: The best bakery I've tried in SF. I'm usually not a fan of the "fruit" in my pastries because the sourness can sometimes overwhelm the flavor; this wasn't the case for Neighbor Bakehouse. I got the blackberry croissant and chocolate chip cookie -- they weren't hot from the oven but still tasted fresh and fluffy and soft. Would definitely go again and again.
author: Khanh P.

description:
The Neighbor Bakehouse offers some excellent and delicious pastries. Mainly open in the mornings, you'll find croissants and tarts for breakfast. Plus other goodies to satisfy for later in the day.  The flavor combinations are unique and frankly, addictive. Yes, a person can be addicted to baked goods. I will find myself calculating when my next trip there will be. The sweeter baked items are just as delicious. Favorites are the Sauerkraut Tart (yes, you heard right), Everything Croissant, Mushroom Tart, Ham and Cheese Bun, and Bostock. Their Bostock is something else. Probably the best one I've had in the Bay Area, or anywhere else.  Sometimes, you may find something not on the menu, such as the scrumptious, savory bread pudding I had one Wednesday. 

I remember first trying one of their sauerkraut concoctions maybe 5 years ago, during an event in Dogpatch. There was no storefront, just a table setup. I think it was Greg Mindel, the founder, who was there listing off what each item was for us.  When it comes to baked goods, sauerkraut doesn't top my list of favored ingredients. But after tasting it, it just worked. Fast forward to this year, I recalled that experience and remembered the name Neighbor. Thanks to a quick internet search, I happily discovered they opened a retail shop. Which, is also their wholesale bakery, I believe. 

They aren't open everyday, usually only from
Wednesday through Sunday.  The hours are early morning through noonish.  Sometimes they may close unexpectedly, so check their website or FB page, before heading there if possible. Don't become as distraught as I was when I arrived to find them closed one day, when I forgot to check their hours. There are some picnic tables set up outside, but no seating inside. 

This bakery is definitely out of my neighborhood, but when I get a chance to detour here, I pick up some of their various offerings. Just enough to share and last a few days. Heated up the next day, they beat most of the pastries I find around the city.  Looking forward to seeing what will be in store next...
author: CE Y.

description: The owner, Christine, is an amazing person and a great baker. This place is one of my favorite places in SF. Some of my favorite pastries are the ginger pull-apart, chocolate doughp bun, chocolate claw, pistachio blackberry twice-baked and raspberry hazelnut twice-baked.
author: Ethan T.

description: Delicious buttery crunch bread!! I love that they have so many different flavored fillings, from sweet to salty! I wish they would stay open longer in the day so I can have more.
author: Julia Z.

description:
I was house-sitting in Dogpatch for a month and it was such a treat to live two blocks from Neighbor Bakehouse!  Totally nondescript on the outside, but the stuff they churn out of this little place...seriously amazing.  Every single item I've had has been incredible, and I've shared with friends and they've been utterly impressed too.

Don't miss the pistachio blackberry croissant and if you're into savory, the sauerkraut cheddar peppadew will blow your mind.  Trust me, it is that good.
author: Joanne G.

description:
This ginger pull apart is a DRRRREEEEAAAMMMMMMMMM. GIMME MORE. 

Service is so sweet and espresso drinks are perfect.
author: Jacquee P.

description: Croissant is the best I've had in the bay area along with Manresa Bread's, I'd say Neigbor's is a bit more buttery. Love the bostock, although I found it a bit heavy compared to B.Pat's version.
author: Ryan S.

description: Oh boy, everything here is baked perfectly. I'll add a list of items the next time we're there.
author: Peter C.

description:
Neighbor Bakehouse is the best!  One of my favorite places in Dogpatch.  Their pastries are so amazing.  I've managed to sample a few and their ham and cheese morning bun is by far the one thing I always have to get!  It's ham and cheese inside of a morning-bun-shaped-croissant that is encrusted in every type of seed possible.  The Blackberry Pistachio Croissant is my second favorite.   

Their coffee, espresso drinks, and tea are also quite tasty!  More so than some of the snobbier cafes located around the city.  

The location is small, the staff are very friendly, and the lines aren't terribly long.  There are two picnic tables out front and two benches.  Quite quaint atmosphere for facing the street.

Update (08/31/2015):  After touring several bakeries in Seattle...Neighbor has the best croissant! Happy Eating all!
author: Cindy L.

description: Absolute favorite bakery in the city. Neighbor Bakehouse is conveniently located off the 23rd Street stop on the T line Muni, close to Dog patch Boulders and Serpentine. It has a host of sweet and savory pastries, most of which I've tried. I highly recommend the pistachio-blackberry croissant, the ginger pull apart, and the cinnamon-almond bostock with a cup of freshly brewed coffee. Usually a few places to sit outside, but I like to take my pastry to go on the way to work or school
author: Rhea M.

description: Believe the damn hype. These are some of the best flavor combinations I have tried in recent memory. Modern takes on all your favorite classics. The twice baked Black Berry Pistachio croissant is an absolute game changer. The everything croissant makes me want to start practicing my "It's not you Bagels it's me" speech.
author: Yoni Z.

description:
Neighbor Bakehouse is amazing. I tried it for the first time today, a beautiful Sunday morning. Everything I ordered was absolutely delicious: 

Croissant (better than Tartine)
Pistachio Blackberry Twice-Baked Croissant (a must-try)
Ginger Pull Apart (yum!)

Yes, I ate everything all by myself. Oink!
author: Kevin D.

description: Excellent pastries, probably best you will find in dogpatch.  Hard to spot from street as its among some store fronts that are inset.  Maybe look for a line.  No inside seating, There are some picnic tables in the front of it that you can eat at.  I'm a fan of filled croissants.  Comparable to B Patisserie, but different fillings like Pistachio Blackberry twice-baked and Raspberry violet twice baked.
author: Jim T.

description:
I work a few blocks away and pass Neighbor all the time. Took me a while, but I finally made my way over and was not disappointed at all.

The pastries here are AMAZING. I've had every sweet baked good they offer. The menu is definitely overwhelming, but if you make your way through, you won't be disappointed. 

Here's a list of my favorite must-tries:
1. Pistachio blackberry twice-baked
This croissant is no joke. It's delicious. The outside is flaky, buttery goodness and the inside is chewy with an amazing mixture of blackberry and pistachio. I always have to buy at least 2. Occasionally there are other berries instead of blackberry, but those variants are just as delicious.

2. Ginger pull apart
Get this. No, seriously, get it. When it comes to amazing, buttery, flaky doughs, Neighbor excels. The taste of ginger comes across well, but it's not overpowering and you really can't stop after just one piece. Heating it up makes it even better.

3. Passion fruit doughp bun
